title: Dinkins Hospitalized With Touch of Flu
description: Looking under the weather, Mayor David N. Dinkins checked into the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center early yesterday with an apparent touch of the flu, and his personal physician later said he was resting comfortably and would be kept overnight as a precaution.

title: For Brooklyn Neighborhood, at Long Last, the Way Is Clear
description: THE first bike over the Williamsburg Bridge's reopened walkway was a beauty: a 1954 Schwinn Black Phantom, big and bulky with whitewall tires. Its owner, Andy Cohen, 26 years old, had waited for that ride since last June, when the decrepit walkway was determined a danger, then abruptly closed.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I feel every household should have a gun. If somebody breaks in, you're more likely to deter them. But I do kind of feel that if you have a gun in the house you should have a soft-point bullet so it won't go through your house into your neighbor's." -- JAMES JENNINGS, a gun enthusiast in Tucson. [ A10:4. ]

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Beauty of the Flat Tax
description: Jerry Brown's upset victory in the Colorado primary has forced his opponents to pay attention to his campaign proposals, even those that sound oddball. Take the tax plan he extols in every debate: Scrap all Federal taxes and replace them with a 13 percent "flat tax" on each taxpayer's personal and corporate income. Mr. Brown is able to set such a low rate because he would eliminate nearly every deduction and exemption. Families would be allowed to deduct only mortgage interest, rent and charitable contributions.

title: Wiland Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Eastco Industries Safety reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Reason for Staten Island to Secede?
description: Staten Island, which, as everybody knows, got its name when an early visitor to New York Harbor leaned over the rail and asked "Is t'at an island?" is wrestling with a new nuance of nomenclature.

title: Royal Palm Beach Colony Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: Dorset Exploration reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: PSI Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included after-tax charge of $ 85 million to cover possible refunds to customers, following a November 1991 decision bu the Indiana Supreme Court to reverse a 1987 Indiana utility regulatory commission order that exempted PSI Energy from reducing its retail rates when the federal income tax rate changed to 34 percent from 46 percent.c-Net income

title: Stacy Waldman Has Wedding
description: Stacy Pamela Waldman, a law student at New York University, and Daniel Adam Alper, a tax lawyer in New York, were married yesterday in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Robert Rothman officiated at Abigail Kirsh at Tappan Hill.

title: Colombia Ends Luxuries at Drug Lord's Jail
description: The Government ordered a crackdown at the jail where the drug cartel leader Pablo Escobar is imprisoned after discovering that it had been equipped with luxuries like carpets, bathtubs and a boardroom table, a newspaper reported today.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The Treasury this week plans to hold only its regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, which is scheduled for today.

title: Long-Sought Indoor Title for Manhattan
description: Manhattan College, which had not won an IC4-A indoor track championship since 1973, finally did it today.

title: Susan Wildfeuer Weds Sim Shapiro
description: Susan Muriel Wildfeuer, an occupational therapist, and Sim Reuven Shapiro, a law student, were married yesterday in Denver. Rabbi Stanley Wagner officiated at Beth Hamidrash Hagadol Congregation.

title: Electronic Tele-Commun reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeLatest quarter and year's share earnings included a restructuring charge of about 19 cents a share.

title: Daleco Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: Wolverine World Wide Inc.  reports earnings for 16wks to Dec 28
description: b-Included a pre-tax charge of $ 7.5 million from settlement of a lawsuit, in the quarter and year.c-Net loss and included a pre-tax charge of $ 11.6 million from restructuring costs and another pre-tax charge of $ 4.6 million in legal costs.

title: Novametrix Medical Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-Net loss

title: Griffin Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Spirit of Newburgh Past Haunts Political Present
description: IF Michael Harrington was a hero of American social welfare advocates in the 1960's, Joseph McDowell Mitchell was their nemesis.

title: Phillips Perera, 58, A Financial Expert For Food Companies
description: Phillips Perera, a business executive and an expert in finance for agriculture and food companies in developing countries, died March 2 at his home in Manhattan. He was 58 years old.

title: Manhattan Stops Iona To Advance to Title Game
description: Despite the absence of starting center Jamal Marshall and five stitches in the forehead of his replacement, David Bernsley, Manhattan still managed to hang on and defeat Iona tonight, 79-78, in a Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference semifinal contest before 9,367 spectators at Knickerbocker Arena.

title: Magna International reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net lossThe results are in Canadian dollars.

title: A Writer Extols His Boyhood Hero
description: For someone who has written a baseball book aimed at fifth- to eighth-grade fans, HOWIE REISER seems curiously cavalier about raising unrealistic expectations in impressionable young minds.

title: Isolated Washington Neighborhood Keeps Wary Eye on Its New Subway
description: For Anacostia, a neighborhood separated from the rest of the nation's capital by the river that bears its name, the recent opening of its first subway stop could mean the end of decades of isolation.

title: Another Vacancy at Top Of Johnson Products
description: The Johnson Products Company, the Chicago-based maker of hair-care products for black consumers, said yesterday that Eric G. Johnson, its president and chief executive, had resigned to pursue personal business interests.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week; Democrats' Diplomacy: They Need Each Other
description: Welcome to the N.F.L.

title: Mayans' 'Big Bird'
description: THE largest Mayan sculpture yet found has been unearthed in Guatemala. The 34-foot-wide, 16-foot-high sculpture was carved about 300 B.C. at the base of the tallest temple pyramid in Nakbe, an ancient Mayan city 350 miles north of Guatemala City.

title: Esquire Radio & Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1990 periods include a one-time gain of $ 327,000, or 68 cents a share.

title: Hockey; Weather Gets Warmer, and Rangers Get Colder
description: For the Rangers, the omens are now in full bloom.

title: Monarchists Dust Off Past To Belgrade Rule
description: On a hill above old Belgrade, about 25,000 Serbs gathered today to sing old nationalist anthems, celebrate their Orthodox faith and repudiate the Communist past. For many in the crowd, this included calls for the restoration as king of Crown Prince Alexander, the London-born head of the family that was Yugoslavia's monarchy until it fled Hitler's Panzers in 1941."

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Media One Campaign That Stumbles to Success, Another That Seldom Stumbles; For Tsongas Camp, Things Go Right 'Now and Then'
description: For the Tsongas campaign, today was an exception.

title: Hockey; Rangers Obtain Wells In a Trade With Sabres
description: General Manager Neil Smith, tinkering with a Ranger team that suddenly needs a tuneup, yesterday sent right-handed defenseman Randy Moller to Buffalo for aging left-handed defenseman Jay Wells.

title: America Only
description: In the wake of the cold war, President Bush calls for America to take its place in a new world order . . . the Republican challenger Patrick Buchanan insists on a policy of America first . . . and the Pentagon now proclaims a global defense policy of America only.

title: Age Before Championships? Not for the Almost-50 Floyd
description: Besides a record that ranks him as an all-time great, Raymond Floyd is destined to leave golf with many treasures. One of the best short games ever seen. The presumptuous verve with which he walks after long putts before they drop. The focused intensity of the glazed on-course expression his peers call The Look. Even the lyrical nickname he doesn't particularly like -- Tempo Raymundo.

title: Yalta Journal; Picture Lenin and the Czar, Communing by the Sea
description: In Warsaw and other Eastern European capitals, the word "Yalta" often conjures up the conference at which the Western Allies of World War II in effect conceded to Stalin the right to dominate the countries from which the Soviet Army was driving its German foe. It meant, until the collapse of Communist rule in 1989, 44 years of subjugation to Soviet power.

title: Alexander's in Talks to Revise Bank Pacts
description: Alexander's Inc., the budget department store chain that occupies some of the world's most valuable real estate, said yesterday that it was negotiating with its banks to revise its loan agreements and to increase its revolving credit lines in an effort to shore up its faltering business.

title: Key Rates
Bills in Trenton Aim at Conduct Of Youngsters
description: New Jersey lawmakers from both sides of the aisle have introduced a spate of bills that attempts to legislate the conduct, and in some instances the morals, of the state's young people and increase the liability of parents who allow their children to stay out late or consistently play hooky.

title: Baker Hints at U.S. Shift On Slovenia and Croatia
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d suggested today that the Bush Administration might be ready to recognize Yugoslavia's breakaway republics after months of delay and deliberation.

title: Argentina Deal Seen for Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it was negotiating to sell 65,000 Ford Tempos to an association of taxi drivers in Argentina. If completed, the deal would be among Ford's largest export orders ever.

title: Accounts
description: * Fisher-Price Inc., East Aurora, N.Y., to Waring & LaRosa Inc., New York, for its Kiddicraft line of products for infants and pre-schoolers. The agency, which already handles other Fisher-Price accounts, said that a print campaign would begin in the fall. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Law Upheld On Zoning For Housing
description: A Superior Court judge has upheld a Connecticut law that was enacted to open the state's suburbs and small towns to builders of affordable housing.

title: Holtzman Bars Contract to Bronx Agency
description: The New York City Comptroller has moved to cancel a new city contract with a private social-service agency in the Bronx where a former official was accused of spending thousands of dollars in public funds on personal expenses and political contributions.

title: Tarpley Joins C.B.A.
description: ROY TARPLEY, banned from the National Basketball Association for refusing to take a mandatory drug test, will return to pro basketball tonight as a member of the Wichita Falls Texans in the Continental Basketball Association.

title: Cajoling Spare Change To Protect Lighthouse
description: It is not customary for Mary Angevine, weekend gatekeeper of the historic lighthouse at Long Island's outermost tip, to hand back change. Rather, she lets the bills lie there at the ticket window between her and the visitors, an open green dare beneath her nimble pitch.

title: Hibernians Lose Round On Parade
description: A judge for New York City's Commission on Human Rights yesterday denied a motion by the St. Patrick's Day Parade sponsor to dismiss discrimination charges against it, leaving open the possibility that the sponsor would be forced to allow a gay group to march in the parade under its own banner.

title: Family of Dead Rock Fan Receives $250,000
description: The family of a rock fan who suffered fatal head injuries when a New Jersey state trooper hit him in the Meadowlands Sports Complex in November 1990 has settled a Federal civil rights suit for $250,000.

title: Eavesdroppers, Beware
description: To the Editor:

title: Mueller Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-After pre-tax unusual charges of $ 44.4 million in the quarter and year.c-Net income and after an extraordinary credit of $ 392,416,000 in the quarter and year from forgiveness of debt, and also included income from fresh start reporting adjustments of $ 56,894,000 in the both periods; the quarter also included a gain of $ 30,420,000 and the year a loss of $ 8,090,000, both from discontinued operations.The year-ago periods' share earnings and shares outstanding are not comparable due to the reorganization in 1990.

title: Long Island Student Wins Westinghouse Contest
description: A Long Island youth who discovered a new way of tracing the history of pollution in bodies of waters won the first-place award in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search yesterday.

title: Careers; Early Start To Job Study In Colleges
description: BIG or small, universities and colleges are worrying more about the job outlook for their students. Perhaps surprisingly though, their concern is not so much for those graduating this recessionary year, but for those who are now just freshmen and sophomores.

title: Review/Music; A Bulgarian State Choir With Regionalism Intact
description: When the Bulgarian State Radio and Television Female Vocal Choir toured the United States in 1988 after the surprising commercial success of its album "Le Mystere des Voix Bulgares" (Nonesuch), the choir's singular sound was enough to enthrall listeners. Singing concert arrangements of traditional songs, usually unaccompanied, the choir of two dozen women sounds both angelic and, to American ears, gorgeously alien. When the choir, conducted by Dora Hristova, came to Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night, some of the novelty had worn off, but familiarity makes the music barely less remarkable.

title: Witness Says Tape May Support Officer's Claim
description: A major witness in the trial of four white police officers in the beating of a black motorist testified today that the videotape of the incident showed the motorist making what might have been an aggressive move toward one of the officers, although she did not recall him doing so.

title: Washington Ordinance Tests Congress
description: The District of Columbia and Congressional conservatives are preparing for a confrontation over a new ordinance to allow unmarried couples to register with the city as domestic partners. Although some members of Congress see the measure as a politically dangerous piece of gay-rights legislation, the liberal city government views it as a test of its sovereignty.

title: 'Weird' Bird Lives In Harems
description: WHILE harems of jealously guarded females are common among mammals, biologists had always thought they did not exist among birds.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There will be 80 candles on the birthday cake -- or, rather, cookie -- that DEBORAH NORVILLE will help blow out tomorrow. She will be helping to celebrate the 80th annivesary of the Girl Scouts of America. The party, on the 86th floor observatory of the Empire State Building, is being given by the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York. More than 50 current and past scouts, including three who won the Golden Eaglet award of the 1920's, will be on hand. Many will stay on for the annual "urban campout" that night in the observatory.

title: Christian Science Head Quits Amid Money Fight
description: The longtime chairman of the Christian Science Church resigned yesterday amid a bitter internal dispute over the church's direction and finances, and the church simultaneously abandoned his ambitious and expensive dream of building a cable television channel into the church's principal ministry to the world.

title: Sports of The Times; This Time Tricky Dick Can't Pass
description: LONG before "point guard" was part of basketball's vocabulary, Dick McGuire was the prototype point guard on the prototype playground court. He not only was ahead of his time, he was often at least one pass ahead of his teammates.

title: H.J. Heinz Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $ 221,459,000 recorded in June 1991 as a result of the sale of Hubinger Co.

title: The New York Premiere Of 1937 Britten Cantata
description: Benjamin Britten's cantata "The Company of Heaven" is to be given its New York premiere in a performance by the Central City Chorus on March 22 at 7 P.M. at the Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue, at 64th Street. The cantata, which was only recently published, was written for a 1937 BBC radio broadcast. It is scored for chorus, soprano and tenor soloists, speakers, timpani, organ and strings.

title: Will the World Conquer Us in '92?
description: Listen carefully to anyone associated with the World League of American Football. Listen very carefully. Replay tapes of their remarks backward (but discard the satanic lyrics). Nearly the same words are repeated, as if in a mantra:

title: Lindros Again Says No
description: Eric Lindros turned down a contract offer from the Quebec Nordiques that would have earned him more than $55 million over 10 years, radio station CJRP in Quebec reported yesterday.

title: Latin Nations Feud Over Cholera Outbreak
description: One year after cholera broke out in Latin America, it carries a stigma that nations and Governments try to avoid at all costs. The fear of being branded as a country unable to control a cholera outbreak is best illustrated by a political battle now going on between Argentina and Peru.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Conservatives; Bush Gets Two Cheers From Religious Right
description: Four years ago South Carolina proved to be the Waterloo for the Presidential hopes of Pat Robertson, the television evangelist who sought to pull together conservative Christians to form a united and potent political force.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY GOTTI LAWYER OUNTERATTACKS

title: Seductively Subtle Art of Japanese Puppets
description: Minosuke Yoshida is a slight, avuncular man with a ready smile and angular features, but when this master of the stage is at his most expressive, filled with wrenching emotion or pathos, his face becomes a blank mask. Instead, as he demonstrated, he conveys feeling with the most subtle movements of his fingers, lending an exquisitely expressive tilt to the head of the traditional puppet in his lap and transforming it into a maiden quivering with grief.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: '900' Phone Number For Political Donors
description: The direct-marketing technology of "900" telephone numbers has been adapted for national political fund-raising in a project sponsored by a Washington-based political action committee.

title: Review/Theater; Fateful Encounters At an Urban Crossroads
description: The intersection of life with chance seems to fascinate Richard Caliban as a playwright and director. In his plays and his productions of plays by other writers, accidents occur that throw widely disparate people into juxtaposition -- accidents that prove to be fateful, even fatal. In "Homo Sapien Shuffle," at the Public Theater, a man is killed in full public view in Grand Central Terminal. But he is not the intended victim. Why was he there, Mr. Caliban asks, and who was meant to die in his place?

title: Review/Music; Trying Out the New Hall at Queens College
description: Subtly, over the last dozen years, the sound of music in New York concert halls has been changing. Merkin Concert Hall, for example, is an almost ideal, intimate setting for chamber music; the sound reaches the ears without even the sense of an "acoustic" ambiance. In addition, the renovations at Weill Recital Hall (formerly Carnegie Recital Hall) and Kathryn Bache Miller Hall at Columbia University have been welcome, along with such new contributions as Gould Hall at the French Institute/ Alliance Francaise and the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: We Need a Global Warming Treaty With Clout; Link With Cholera
description: To the Editor

title: Intel Suit on Chip Transfer
description: The Intel Corporation today asked for a court order to block Chips and Technologies Inc. from transferring its design for a clone of Intel's best-selling computer chip to other manufacturers.

title: F.D.I.C. Backs Deal By Milken
description: Winning the right to review some financial data in the deal, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reversed course yesterday and agreed to support a plan allowing Michael R. Milken, along with hundreds of other former executives of Drexel Burnham Lambert and Drexel's insurers, to put up $1.3 billion to settle all civil litigation against them.

title: Lawyers Under Fire; With U.S. Willing to Go After Law Firms, More Whistle-Blowing on Clients Is Likely
description: Leaders of some of the nation's largest law firms disagreed yesterday over whether the quick decision on Sunday by Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler to settle a Federal lawsuit was a desperate attempt to save itself or, in effect, a no-contest plea to charges that it withheld damaging information about a client from Government savings and loan investigators.

title: Amid 'Shortage,' Young Physicists See Few Jobs
description: EVEN as leading scientists warn that America's educational system is failing to produce scientists fast enough to fill a glaring projected shortage, many young physicists contend that universities are already turning out far more physicists than there are permanent jobs.

title: Inside-Trading Case Settled
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged a former employee of Bear, Stearns & Company with using inside information to profit on two acquisitions by the Chemical Banking Corporation.

title: Lehman Bros.' London Move
description: Lehman Brothers International Ltd. named Christopher Deuters, a Citicorp official, managing director and the head of global foreign exchange.

title: Times Tells Deliverers to Expect Layoffs
description: The New York Times Company has notified the union at a wholesale newspaper distribution operation that all delivery employees will be laid off on May 11, when the Times Company expects to take control of the operation.

title: Basketball; Miami Wins Women's Big East
description: Even though they had won at least 20 games in each of the last three seasons, no one expected too much of the Miami women's basketball team during its first season in the Big East.

title: Value City Dept. Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: The shares earnings are reflected by 30,525,000 shares outstanding, the total after giving effect to the 2-for-1 stock split, which was effective at the close of business on Nov. 18, 1991.Prior year earnings are pro forma as if the company was subject to taxes on income and as if the sale of common shares in its initial public offering has occurred at the beginning of the fiscal year.

title: Lone Superpower Plan: Ammunition for Critics
description: The Pentagon's draft policy statement that foresees a one-superpower world in which no collection of allies or foes is allowed to become a rival reflects intense pressure in the American military establishment to define a robust mission for itself in the post-cold-war era.

title: Gotti Defense Challenges Details in Murder Story
description: A defense lawyer scornfully attacked the credibility of Salvatore Gravano yesterday, challenging his testimony that four gunmen all wore white raincoats and Russian fur hats when they killed Paul Castellano.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., Los Angeles, a retailer, named Larry G. Petersen executive vice president and chief financial officer. * Core Industries, Bloomfield Hills, Mich., a maker of electronics and other products, named David R. Zimmer president, chief executive and a director.

title: Marshall Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The year-ago 9 months' share earnings included a net after-tax gain of 3 cents a share from the sale of a facility in August 1990.

title: Q&A
description: Pigeon Colors

title: Business Scene; Moscow Subway Defies the Odds
description: EVERY Moscow subway station has a digital clock that if it were mounted in a New York subway station would be a source of endless public razzing. The clocks time the intervals between trains. Each has only three digits: two that count seconds and one for minutes. The message is that trains are never more than 10 minutes apart, a boast the New York subway system does not dare to make.

title: Staples Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $ 46,000 in the quarter and $ 1.2 million, or 7 cents a share, in the year, from utilization of net operating loss carryforwards.c-After extraordinary credits of $ 97,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 1,545,000, or 10 cents a share, in the year, from utilization of net operating loss carryforwards.Year-ago periods' income from continuing operations included a non-recurring charge of $ 2,053,000 related to the acquisition of lease rights.

title: Electrocom Automation Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Pro forma because the company operated as an S corporation until it went public in January 1992.

title: Hechinger Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-After extraordinary unusual pre-tax charges of $ 8,033,000 associated with the closing of seven Hechinger stores, the sale of the company's accounts receivables to an affiliate of General Electric Capital Corp., and an accounting charge related to Home Quarters' adoption of the LIFO inventory method.The company noted that its latest fourth quarter included favorable adjustments related to the LIFO inventory method and inventory acquisition costs were $ 2.2 million, compared with none in the year-ago quarter.

title: Top Health Official Demands Abolition Of 'Joe Camel' Ads
description: The Surgeon General and the American Medical Assocation joined yesterday to demand that the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company stop using the cartoon character Joe Camel in all advertising and promotions for its Camel cigarettes. The unusual demand, which was rebuffed by the company, intensifies moves against a ubiquitous character long criticized as specifically designed to appeal to children.

title: Note and Bond Rally Continues
description: Treasury notes and bonds yesterday continued the rally that began Friday as investors and speculators seemed to have decided that the sharp increase in yields on those securities the last two months has made them much more attractive.

title: U.S. AGENCIES SPLIT OVER NORTH KOREA
description: The State Department is disputing the prediction by Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, that North Korea is on the verge of becoming a nuclear power, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Pistol Packs Glamour, Power And Reputation as a Menace
description: To Mike Solo, marketing and sales director at the Intratec gun plant here, the Tec-9 semiautomatic pistol the company makes is a "high-spirited" firearm ideal for home protection or target practice and a "fun gun" avidly sought by weekend shooters and collectors because Intratec knows how to "give people what turns them on."

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Unusual Use of the First Amendment Overturns a Killer's Death Sentence
description: The Supreme Court overturned a death sentence today on the ground that the prosecution violated a convicted murderer's First Amendment rights by telling the jury that he belonged to a white racist prison gang called the Aryan Brotherhood.

title: Faster Chip Technology Developed
description: A Silicon Valley start-up company said today that it had developed a technology to vastly increase the speed of memory chips and computers and that it had licensed the technology to three big Japanese chip makers.

title: To Aid Understanding Of Mental Disorders
description: To the Editor:

title: Basketball; Here Comes the Big Guy, Just in Time for Big East
description: Robert Werdann felt like a rookie again. During his first scrimmage in nearly two months, the senior center of the St. John's Redmen found himself on the move, near the basket, in the type of situation he has experienced hundreds, maybe thousands, of times.

title: Milton Gladstone, 77, A Retired Publisher
description: Milton H. Gladstone, a retired publisher of how-to and test-preparation materials in New York, died on Feb. 21 at the Cabrini Medical Center. He was 77 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Accountability by Sledgehammer
description: Many hands worked the frauds and failures of the savings and loan industry, which are costing taxpayers billions in bailouts and lost savings. Incompetent or crooked managers plundered thrift institutions and overwhelmed regulators with legions of lawyers and accountants, and pressure from friendly members of Congress. Some of the blameworthy have been held to account while others, like the "Keating Five" gang of Senators, have escaped with wrist-slappings.

title: How Holyfield-Bowe Fell Apart
description: Since heavyweight Riddick Bowe turned pro in 1989, his manager, Rock Newman, has shrewdly maneuvered him toward the top of the rankings and into position for an eventual shot at the title.

title: How the Democrats Can Win
description: The state of the Democratic Presidential race recalls Will Rogers's rueful confession: "I belong to no organized political party; I am a Democrat." With three major candidates in the race, many still hope that a savior will come in from the sidelines and stave off defeat.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12 NIXON CHIDES BUSH ON RUSSIA AID

title: Vitamins Win Support as Potent Agents of Health
description: LONG consigned to the fringes of medicine and accorded scarcely more credibility than crystal-rubbing or homeopathy, the study of how vitamins affect the body and help prevent chronic diseases is now winning broad attention and respect among mainstream medical researchers.

title: Stocks Rise in Tokyo
description: Stock prices rebounded this afternoon to closed slightly higher in Tokyo. The Nikkei index of 225 issues, which was down 76.87 points at midday, ended the day up 56.91, or nearly three-tenths of 1 percent, to 20,854.59. On Monday, the Nikkei fell 195.31 points.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. May Shift on Yugoslavia

title: Review/Television; A Look Inside a Hospital for the Criminally Insane
description: "Asylum," at 10 tonight on HBO, offers a close and sometimes painful look at the inmates of Patton State Hospital in San Bernardino County, California, home to people judged criminally insane. The first glimpses of them, huddled alone or answering the off-screen interviewer or undergoing therapy, seem random. But, as the hour goes along, you realize you are watching some of these men and women struggling to exorcise their personal demons, while others may merely be trying to con their public guardians.

title: Nixon Scoffs at Level of Support For Russian Democracy by Bush
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon has sharply criticized President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d for what he calls the Administration's pathetic support of the democratic revolution in Russia. He says one of the historic opportunities of this century is being missed.

title: Albany Getting an Earful Over Congressional Map
description: It is not every day that Saul Weprin, the Speaker of the New York State Assembly, gets telephone calls from the likes of Shimon Peres and Walter F. Mondale. But then Congressional redistricting is far from an everyday matter.

title: Cuomo Unveils Bond Plan In an Effort to Create Jobs
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today unveiled an $800 million economic development bond act proposal that is aimed at creating jobs for New York's failing economy but that represents, aides say, a scaled-back version of what he originally hoped to propose.

title: Review/Fashion; Suits Take Many Guises In Milan
description: By simply switching his show from the last day of the week to the first, Giorgio Armani gave a new perspective to the Italian fall and winter openings.

title: American Israeli Paper Mills reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
We Need a Global Warming Treaty With Clout; Environment Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: 4-Year-Old Bronx Boy Is Beaten and Burned, and His Parents Are Charged
description: A 4-year-old boy, whose body the police said was covered with bruises and whose feet were red from burns, was listed in stable condition yesterday in a Bronx hospital, and his parents were under arrest and charged in his abuse.

title: CTS Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 1.7 million charge for restructuring and other related expenses of several businesses and for planned expenses incurred in connection with expansions in Scotland and Thailand.

title: Paying Respects To TV
description: Is "Beverly Hills 90210" worthy of serious analysis at, of all places, a fine-arts museum? Is "Hill Street Blues" comparable to Shakespeare? Are television shows like "A Different World," "Maude" and "Star Trek: The Next Generation," cultural breakthroughs?

title: J. P. Morgan Out $50 Million In Mortgage-Backed Trades
description: J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that it had lost $50 million on mortgage-backed securities so far this year and that the head of the unit that trades in the investments had resigned.

title: Rykoff-Sexton Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 2,610,000.

title: Where Coffins Come in Size Young
description: When the echo of gunshots dies down and the smoke fades, Benjamin Robinson goes to work. He hauls a gurney from his hearse, wheels it through the Kings County morgue to the refrigerator where the lifeless, blood-streaked body of Teraya Starnes, forever 16, waits for the final trip home to Bedford-Stuyvesant.

title: Afghan President Says U.S. Should See Him as Ally Against Militant Islam
description: Abandoned by his former benefactors in Moscow and cast somewhat adrift in the new politics of the region, Afghanistan's President made an impassioned appeal to the United States today to help his country become a bulwark against the spread of Islamic fundamentalism in Central Asia.

title: Amid Fervor and Memories, Begin Is Buried in Jerusalem
description: With old comrades and their children singing a militant Zionist anthem at his graveside, former Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel was laid to rest today in the rocky soil of the Mount of Olives, overlooking this city of troubles and dreams.

title: John Forsyth Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 1.1 million provision for non-collectible receivables following the action of a major undisclosed customer in seeking protection under the company creditors arrangement act in December for both the quarter and year.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Leona Helmsley Is Told She May Have to Serve Jail Term
description: With Leona Helmsley quietly sobbing in the front row and her lawyer arguing that a jail term would be a death sentence for Mrs. Helmsley and her husband, Harry, a Federal judge warned yesterday that the self-styled hotel queen would get no special treatment from him.

title: O'Brien Staying at B.C.
description: Boston College has given JIM O'BRIEN a multiyear contract extension as a reward for leading the Eagles to their best Big East record since he took over as head coach in 1986.

title: By Design; Spring Tonic in Straw
description: The men's wear influence on women's dress is only just beginning. By next fall women may well be shoulder deep in natty tweeds and tailored attire. Right now, they can ease into the feeling with a hat.

title: Folk Remedy Seems to Help Fight Vaginal Yeast Infections
description: EATING yogurt has long been popular among alternative healers as a remedy for vaginal yeast infections. Because scientific evidence of its powers to cure has remained elusive, however, most doctors have hesitated to recommend it seriously as treatment for this ailment, which afflicts half of all women at some time in their lives.

title: Machado Can't Leave
description: The Venezuelan judge who freed JULIO MACHADO from prison on Friday ruled yesterday that the Milwaukee Brewers' relief pitcher must stay in Venezuela for the time being.

title: Another Year for Brown
description: The American League president, BOBBY BROWN, agreed yesterday to a one-year contract extension through Dec. 31, 1993.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Bowing Out; Congratulating the Remaining Candidates, Harkin Ends Campaign
description: Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, as expected, withdrew today from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination, still embracing his unabashed message of liberalism that failed to catch fire during his six-month campaign.

title: Gorbachev the Tourist Finds Admirers in Germany
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, no longer beloved at home, is enjoying a hero's welcome during a triumphant eight-day tour of Germany.

title: Haunting Effects Of Line Drives
description: The imprint of stitchwork ran in a neat crescent across Wally Whitehurst's forearm. Call them the tracks of his fears.

title: American Software Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Baseball; 2 Tests and 3 Strikes: Yanks Say They're Finished With Perez
description: Angry over reports that suspended Yankee pitcher Pascual Perez questioned the results of his recent positive drug tests, General Manager Gene Michael today called Perez's claim "preposterous" and said the team had no intention of taking him back when his one-year suspension ends, even though it will retain the rights to the right-hander.

title: Patterns
description: Who Knows What's Real?

title: Munson Campbell, 67, Pro Hockey Executive
description: Munson Campbell, a former executive of two National Hockey League teams and a former advertising executive at The New York Times, died last Tuesday while on vacation in Barbados. He was 67 years old.

title: Venture Capital Funds on Upswing
description: Venture capital funds, bloated in the mid-1980's but famished for the last few years, are again enticing investors.

title: Stock Prices End Day Mixed, With Dow Down by 6.48
description: Stocks closed mixed in thin trading yesterday as investors found little reason to buy. A few issues, which appeared attractive after recent sell offs, drew some interest.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Assessment; Eyeing November, Democrats Shiver
description: Despite all the partisan hullabaloo leading up to Super Tuesday, all the proclamations of inevitable victory in November, a gnawing anxiety grips Southern Democrats. They have a wounded bird in their sights, but they fear they lack the ammo to bring him down.

title: Voting Plan Approved by Veto-Proof Margin
description: In a vote that brought together an unusually combustible mix of political forces, the New York State Legislature approved a plan tonight for redistricting itself by a margin that would be large enough to override a threatened veto by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: New York Chamber Ensemble Florence Gould Hall

title: BRIEFS
description: * Elf Aquitaine, France's state-controlled oil company, has had its share price set by the Government at 360 francs, or $63.60, for the 2.3 percent stake of the company to be sold. * Ford Motor Co., Detroit, introduced a 32-valve version of its V-8 engine. The four-cam, 4.6-liter modular engine will be manufactured at Ford's Romeo, Mich., plant for use in the 1992 Lincoln Mark VIII.

title: Haiti's Ousted Leader to Seek Support in U.S.
description: Fearing that the military will try to thwart a recently negotiated plan for his return, the exiled President of Haiti intends to bring his case for increased pressure on the Haitian junta directly to the American people this week.

title: Frederick E. Horn; Accountant, 79
description: Dr. Frederick E. Horn, a certified public accountant who taught at Columbia University for many years, died on Feb. 28 at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 79 years old and lived in Ridgewood.

title: Lofty Instruments Discern Traces of Ancient Peoples
description: WITH lofty perspective and vision no human eye can match, advanced technologies for surveying the landscape from satellites, the space shuttle and airplanes are changing the practices of archeologists and paleontologists exploring the buried remnants of past life.

title: Bridge
description: The diagramed deal, from a Calcutta event played Saturday at the Young Men's Philanthropic League, at 4 East 80th Street, is a tale of two leads. At one table the bidding followed the diagramed route to three no-trump, which appears easy to make.

title: New Technique in Lab Prevents Rejection Of Organ Transplants
description: IN experiments that may revolutionize organ transplants, scientists have temporarily paralyzed the immune systems of mice, slipped in hearts from unrelated mice and watched with astonishment as the animals regained their normal immune systems but did not reject their transplanted hearts.

title: Basketball; Manhattan Squanders Chance to Gain Title
description: The Manhattan Jaspers, who have waited 34 years for a return trip to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, squandered their chance in the final two minutes of their Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference championship game against La Salle tonight.

title: French Socialists Look to Rightist Discontent
description: By condoning a series of stormy demonstrations against the far-right National Front, France's faltering Socialist Government has turned the front's leader, Jean-Marie Le Pen, into the central figure of the campaign for crucial regional elections this month.

title: Amy Ogden Welcher; Church Leader, 104
description: Amy Ogden Welcher, a founder and first national president of Church Women United, a national ecumenical organization, died on Feb. 21 at her home at Avery Heights in Hartford. She was 104 years old.

title: How to Lose the Cold War
description: President Bush, on the defensive against "America Firster" Patrick Buchanan and "America Come Home" Democrats, is in danger of snatching defeat from the jaws of cold war victory.

title: Citicorp Names Briton To Head Asset Group
description: Citicorp has decided to centralize control of its large and far-flung investment advisory service and has hired W. Neville Bowen, a British executive, to run the new group, to be called Global Asset Management.

title: N.H.L. Players and Owners Break Off Talks
description: Contract negotiations between the National Hockey League Players Association and league owners broke off last night with little significant movement toward a settlement as the threat of a strike continued.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans; President Focuses on 'Family Values'
description: With Presidential primaries fast approaching in the Midwest's most urban states, President Bush declared today that the problems of big cities were rooted in the collapse of the family, and that the need for new solutions to the crisis was urgent and clear.

title: Richard Moser, 82, Rackets Investigator, Is Dead
description: Richard Goodwin Moser, who served as chief counsel to the Senate Committee on Organized Crime headed by Senator Estes Kefauver and who was chairman of the professional ethics committees of the New York City and State bar associations, died Tuesday in San Simeon by the Sound, a nursing home in Greenport, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived on Shelter Island.

title: Observer; Mesut, Ayaz and Franjo
description: Once in a blue moon I wander into the foreign-news pages of The New York Times and always come out exhilarated. My doctors think it's escaping the suffocating languors of the post-cold-war, small-bore American news that does the trick.

title: La Mama Runs Short Of Money And Time
description: The La Mama Experimental Theater Club, a downtown theater institution for 30 years, may soon close its doors.

title: Scheib Names President
description: Earl Scheib Inc., the operator of automobile paint shops, today named Donald R. Scheib president and chief executive, succeeding his late father. The company also said it was not for sale. Donald Scheib had been a vice president of the company. Irwin R. Buchalter was named chairman, an office also held by Earl Scheib, who died Feb. 29 at the age of 85.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primaries and Caucuses; CAMPAIGNERS RUSH TO SUPER TUESDAY WITH A TESTY EDGE
description: The three remaining Democratic Presidential candidates scoured Florida and New England for votes yesterday, in person and on television, on the eve of 11 Super Tuesday contests that will choose 783 convention delegates and set the stage for a potential showdown next week in the industrial Midwest.

title: Hewlett's 'Consummate Strategist'
description: As a young manager at the Hewlett-Packard Company two decades ago, Richard A. Hackborn was once taken aside by William Hewlett, the company's co-founder, and given a piece of advice that kept Hewlett-Packard from a head-on collision with I.B.M. in mainframe computers. "Never try to take a fortified hill," Mr. Hewlett said, "especially if the army on top is bigger than your own."

title: World's Rarest Member of Dog Family Faces Extinction
description: IN the southern Ethiopian mountains, a jackal considered to be the world's rarest member of the dog family is faced with extinction, zoologists say.

title: On My Mind; Candidates And the Question
description: Even before he is sworn in, the man who wins the election will have to face for himself the most important question of his term.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: New Sounds Merkin Concert Hall

title: Honda Plans Site
description: Honda North America Inc. plans to invest an additional $25 million to construct an administration, purchasing and design facility at its Marysville, Ohio, car assembly complex by mid-1993. Honda made the announcement today as it displayed a $27 million, 81,000-square-foot expansion of its research and development activities in Marysville, marking completion of the first phase of the expansion announced in the summer of 1990.

title: I.M.F. Is Found to Spur Growth, at Social Cost
description: A report by an independent panel of economists concludes that developing countries that follow the programs of the International Monetary Fund usually make substantial cuts in social welfare spending as well as large cuts in their top income tax rates.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about poverty on the East End of Long Island referred incorrectly to a fund raiser for a food bank and misidentified her former position. She is Mardythe DiPirro, the former supervisor of Southampton, not East Hampton.

title: General Host Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
description: b-After an extraordinary charge related to retirement of debt of $ 860,000 for both the quarter and year, and the year also included income from discontinued operations of $ 5,940,000, or 33 cents a share.c-Net incomeLatest year's income from continuing operations of $ 8,703,000, or 48 cents a share, included a gain of $ 7.8 million, or 43 cents a share, on sale of interest in Calloway's Nursery Inc.The latest results are audited.

title: Revco Expects an End To Long Bankruptcy
description: Revco D.S. Inc., the drugstore chain that has been in bankruptcy since 1988, today was on the verge of emerging from Chapter 11 after nearly all its creditors agreed to back the retailer's reorganization plan.

title: Burke's Next Stop: Minors in San Diego
description: Goaltender SEAN BURKE, who led the Canadian team to a silver medal in the recent Winter Olympics, signed a contract on Sunday night with the San Diego Gulls of the International Hockey League.

title: Basketball; Knicks Take Bus and Pass a Milestone
description: It took the Knicks all of last season to win 39 games. This season, they have done it with 20 games left to play.

title: Unusual Alliances Form on Tax Bill
description: Like sports fans speculating on the possible draft picks by pro teams, senators and their aides are now guessing what amendments will be proposed right after the Senate takes up tax legislation on Tuesday and which will be conspicuous by their absence.

title: LeBlanc Gets His Due
description: RAY LeBLANC, goaltending hero for the United States Olympic team in France, will get his one-game reward tonight when he appears in net for the Blackhawks in Chicago against the San Jose Sharks.

title: Baseball; Howe Tries Hard to Keep From Striking Out
description: There was no more heartwarming and triumphant story in sports last year than Yankee pitcher Steve Howe's comeback. And none that has greater potential for heartbreak than Steve Howe's story this spring.

title: Books of The Times; America's Big Built-In Gamble
description: Crapshoot Rolling the Dice on the Vice Presidency By Jules Witcover 450 pages. Crown. $25. 'The President Has Been Shot' Confusion, Disability and the 25th Amendment in the Aftermath of the Attempted Assassination of Ronald Reagan By Herbert L. Abrams Illustrated. 363 pages. W. W. Norton. $22.95.

title: New Loan for Egypt
description: Egypt has received a $220 million World Bank loan to assist a power project. The loan is for 20 years at a variable interest rate, which is currently 7.73 percent, the World Bank said. There is a five-year grace period. The project, which will cost $1.4 billion, involves building thermal power stations.

title: CSS Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Group to Get Lottery Prize, Officials Say
description: A $5 million gamble has apparently paid off for a group of Australian investors.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House; White House 'Funnel' Directs Aid To States With Primaries Nearing
description: The favors that President Bush dispensed as he campaigned throughout the South last week were a result of a formal, systematic effort to coordinate the policies and actions of the Federal Government with the political operations of the President's re-election campaign, say Administration officials and campaign workers.

title: I've Got the World on a Disk
description: CD-ROM, a technology that used to be as exciting as a 10,000-page statistical database, is trying to enter the consumer and education markets on the coattails of its flashier cousin, the audio compact disk.

title: Trustees Set For Ex-Chief
description: Trustees were appointed today to run the estate of Asil Nadir, former chief executive of Polly Peck International P.L.C. of Britain.

title: WestAir Holding reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Stop & Shop Companies reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 8.6 million from the early retirement of debt in the quarter and year.

title: Lawter International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest share earnings for the quarter and year reflects a 4-for-3 stock split declared Nov. 11, 1991 to shareholders of record Nov. 22, 1991.

title: 2 Large Agencies Merge in San Diego
description: ADC Stoorza and Franklin & Associates, two of San Diego's three largest agencies, plan to merge through an acquisition of Franklin by Stoorza, Zeigaus & Metzger Inc., ADC Stoorza's parent company.

title: Bankruptcy Plan By Sunshine Unit
description: Sunshine Precious Metals Inc. said it would file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after bondholders rejected a silver-indexed bond exchange offer. The Sunshine Mining Company, parent of Sunshine Precious Metals, gave holders of its silver-indexed bonds the choice of accepting the exchange outside of bankruptcy court, or approving it as part of a prepackaged Chapter 11 reorganization plan, said a Sunshine spokesman, William Davis.

title: QVC Network Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $ 868,000 in the quarter and $ 2,108,000 in the year, both on writeoffs of debt placement fees, net of tax benefit.c-Net loss

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Plastic Containers Inc., Syosset, L.I., has filed for $100 million of senior secured notes, due 2001, to be offered through Citicorp Securities Markets Inc. The company is 50 percent owned by Viatech Inc. and 50 percent by Merrywood Inc. Common * Burnham Pacific Properties Inc., San Diego, said it had completed a combined offering of 1.725 million common shares at $16 each and $75 million of 8 1/2 percent debentures, for a total of $102.6 million, through National Westminster Bank's capital markets branch in New York. Burnham is a real estate investment trust that owns and manages 19 commercial properties in San Diego, Orange and Los Angeles Counties. Ratings * Toronto Dominion Bank Ltd.'s long-term debt has been downgraded by Standard & Poor's to AA from AA+, and the issues have been removed from S.& P.'s Creditwatch. The rating service cited the "continued worsening of the bank's asset quality and expectation of a prolonged decline of future profitabilty levels." * Infinity Broadcasting Corp.'s senior subordinated debentures have been assigned a B2 rating by Moody's, which has raised the company's existing senior subordinated notes to B2 from B3. Moody's said the company's capital structure had been improved by an equity offering. Infinity, based in New York City, operates 17 radio stations in large national markets.

title: Dinkins Returns to Hospital After Blood Infection Is Found
description: After briefly leaving his sickbed to sign some bills at City Hall, Mayor David N. Dinkins was readmitted to the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center yesterday for treatment of what his doctors said was a bacterial infection in his blood, perhaps transmitted through an old hernia scar.

title: The Courage to Make Peace
description: Menachem Begin, who died yesterday, transformed Israel in two important ways. Fifteen years ago he led the right-wing Likud bloc to triumph, ending 30 years of Labor Party dominance and shifting the balance of Israeli politics. Months later, he boldly grasped the olive branch offered by Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt. He agreed to trade the land of Sinai for the peace of Camp David, thus securing Israel's first -- and only -- peace treaty with an Arab neighbor.

title: Chess
description: Most players are more than happy to succeed now and then with unclear, speculative attacking play, but for the world champion, Gary Kasparov of Russia, it's his accustomed style. Incredibly confident, he makes violent attacks, replete with heavy sacrifices, work for him again and again.

title: Panel Approves Compromise in Wage Bill
description: The Republican-controlled Assembly Labor Committee voted today to send to the full Assembly an amended bill that would reduce by half a planned 80-cent-an-hour increase but would still make New Jersey's minimum wage among the highest in the nation.

title: U.S. Is Expected to Pressure India on Nuclear Issue
description: The Bush Administration is expected to press India in high-level talks this week to drop its longstanding opposition to signing a treaty limiting the spread of nuclear arms, American officials say. New Delhi will also be asked to join in regional talks with Pakistan on controlling nuclear development.

title: 9 Ounces of Agile Memory, to Go
description: DON'T let anyone put a Psion Series 3 in your hand. To see it is to want it.

title: The Castration Option
description: Steven Allen Butler of Houston, Tex., is not a man to be trusted around little girls. While he was on probation for molesting a 7-year-old, he repeatedly raped a 13-year-old. Mr. Butler, however, is not going to prison. He requested surgical castration rather than a life sentence, and Judge Michael McSpadden said O.K. If Mr. Butler behaves himself for the next 10 years, his conviction for his second sexual assault will be removed from his record.

title: Some Big Changes At Martin Marshall
description: Martin Marshall Jaccoma Mitchell in New York has changed its management and its name with the retirement of John Martin, 50 years old, as the agency's president and chief executive.

title: Ezra Denerstein, 73, Finance Executive For Bank Company
description: Ezra J. Denerstein, president of Sterling Bancorp, a bank-holding corporation with headquarters in New York, died in New York Hospital on Feb. 22. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Amsterdam Schoenberg Ensemble Merkin Concert Hall

title: Suspect in Killing Arrested
description: The state police arrested a suspect today in a shooting that killed a restaurant manager and wounded an employee. Charles Williams, 29 years old, was arrested about 9:45 P.M. after a chase that may have involved gunfire, said Jack Smith, a senior investigator with the Burlington County prosecutor's office. The suspect was taken to Memorial Hospital of Burlington County in Mount Holly, Mr. Smith said. He will be charged with murder and attempted murder, officials said. The fatal holdup Sunday was the second in a week at the McDonald's restaurant on Route 130 and York Street.

title: American Stores Co.  reports earnings for 13wks to Feb 1
description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 40,734,000.Share earnings reflects the 2-for-1 stock split on July 16, 1991.The company elected early adoption of SFAS No. 106, Employers' Accounting for Postretirement Benefits other than pensions, effective in the first quarter of 1991.The company said its 1991 earnings include a pretax LIFO charge of $ 34.9 million, compared with a charge of $ 50 million in 1990. In 1991, the company also recorded a $ 19.6 million pretax charge in connection with these claims, and pretax gains of $ 103.6 million, or 90 cents a share, on the disposition of assets, primarily from the sale of the Alpha Beta Co. subsidiary.The company also said net earnings for 1990 include pretax earnings of $ 9.4 milliin, or 8 cents a share, from non-recurring items, primarily gains on the sale of assets, including Buttrey Food & Drug.

title: Review/Dance; Insistent Music With 2 Responses
description: What made the program that Feld Ballets/NY presented Sunday night at the Joyce Theater especially fascinating was the fact that it included two very different choreographic responses by Eliot Feld to insistent pieces of music.

title: Pension Changes Urged After Maxwell Scandal
description: The ease with which Robert Maxwell plundered hundreds of millions of dollars from employee pension funds shows that Britain's regulatory system needs to be greatly strengthened, a parliamentary committee investigating the scandal said today in a report.

title: People
description: * Pamela D. Brick was named to the new position of president at Genecom, New York, the medical education unit of Robert A. Becker Inc. She was previously a vice president and group project manager at Health Science Communications Inc., New York. * Michael LaMonica was named creative director at Beber Silverstein & Partners, Miami. He was previously a creative director at Bauerlein Inc., New Orleans.

title: Otto Klineberg, Who Helped Win '54 Desegregation Case, Dies at 92
description: Otto Klineberg, whose pioneering studies on the intelligence scores of black students helped win the Supreme Court's landmark school desegregation case in 1954, died on Friday at the Carriage Hill nursing home in Bethesda, Md. He was 92 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: We Need a Global Warming Treaty With Clout
description: To the Editor:

title: Court's Ruling On Terms Gives Boost to Backers
description: The United States Supreme Court today left intact a 1990 initiative limiting the terms of California State officeholders, thereby giving a shot of adrenaline to similar measures under consideration in at least 16 states.

title: Here, All the Treasures Are on Paper
description: HERE'S a story for those people who read prose for pleasure, who hold a new book, even a new old book, full of expectation and exciting promise as if it had been written just for them and left, like a sleeping princess in a witch's spell, as long as necessary for the appropriately appreciative eyes to arrive. You can spot these addicted readers easily. They're the ones who must study the remote channel-changer every time they seek the right button to flee "Jeopardy."

title: Market Place; Ionics: Pure Play In Pure Water
description: MORE than 40 years ago, a group of venture capitalists and engineers in the Boston area founded Ionics Inc., a company built on the belief that purifying water would become a big business. Investors in Ionics think that day has arrived.

title: Removal of Nitrates
description: Scientists say they have found a way to use a plant enzyme to rid underground drinking water of nitrates, a dangerous and increasingly widespread pollutant. They say the method is very effective, but they still must work out technical problems to make it economically feasible.

title: Basketball; Fordham Hopes to Avoid Another N.C.A.A. Almost
description: N.I.T. N.I.T. N.I.T.

title: Thor Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Sphinx Poses Riddle About Its Own Fate
description: THE Sphinx, ravaged by time and the crush of human beings who come to gaze or settle near its great stone paws, has coughed up a new riddle for the modern age: What can be done to save the ancient monument?

title: Dress Barn Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
Candidates Should Get With the Campaign Finance Program
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Overheard at the buffet supper at JIM and KATE LEHRER'S home in the Cleveland Park section of Washington Sunday evening: "This is the closest thing to a political-media-literary salon in Washington -- the A list of press in town."

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I will pay any price, bear any burden, learn to speak Greek, develop a Southern accent, or learn to wear a turtleneck to insure that a Democrat is elected President in 1992." -- SENATOR TOM HARKIN. [ A20:3. ]

title: Sanctions on Iraq Punish the Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Rexene Official to Replace Chief Who Forced Him Out
description: The Rexene Corporation said yesterday that Andrew J. Smith had rejoined the troubled petrochemical company as chief executive.

title: Menachem Begin, Guerrilla Leader Who Became Peacemaker
description: Menachem Begin, the Israeli Prime Minister who made peace with Egypt, lived much of his life in the opposition. A Jewish underground leader before Israel gained independence in 1948, he openly fought the established Zionist leadership of the struggle against British rule.

title: 'Anglo' Vote May Decide Apartheid Referendum
description: With a week to go before South Africa's whites vote on whether to continue the Government's pursuit of an end to apartheid, both those for and against agree that the attitude of this country's English-speaking whites may prove decisive.

title: Devlieg-Bullard reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring charge of about $ 3 million for both the quarter and 6 months.c-Net income

title: Morgan Stanley Makes High-Level Changes
description: In response to the growth of its global operations and the increasing complexity of its domestic ones, Morgan Stanley Group Inc. announced high-level changes yesterday that included the promotion of John Mack to head a new operating committee.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primaries and Caucuses; CLINTON TAKES FLORIDA EASILY, SWEEPING PRIMARIES IN SOUTH; PROTEST VOTES STILL DOG BUSH
description: Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas dominated former Senator Paul E. Tsongas today in the biggest test so far of the primary season, winning a string of victories in his native South, including a decisive triumph in Florida.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Assessment; Super Tuesday Transforms Campaign
description: Southern Democratic leaders achieved today what they sought in vain to do four years ago: They gave a mighty heave forward to the Presidential bid of a moderate candidate from their own region.

title: Integrated in Plan To Sell Assets
description: Integrated Resources Inc. agreed to sell its non-cash assets to Penguin Realty Associates, an affiliate of the Pritzker family of Chicago, for about $200 million. Integrated, a financial services company and real estate syndicator, filed for bankruptcy court protection in February 1990.

title: Doctors Give Johnson Green Light
description: Sounding more and more like a man planning to end his retirement, Magic Johnson said yesterday that his doctors have given him permission to return to professional basketball.

title: Personal Health
description: BEVERLY W. was a 35-year-old teacher when a voice disorder changed her tutorial tones into a whispery rasp that threatened her career, her social life and her self-esteem. Harry S. was a 60-year-old news reporter when the same disorder turned his once-fluid interviews into slow and painful exercises.

title: Maine Public Service reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cardis Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit related to the restructuring of debt of $ 21,459,000, or $ 9.61 a share.c-Net lossPrior year periods have been restated to give effect to the 1-for-20 reverse stock split effective concurrently with the recapitalization approved by shareholders in October 1991.

title: Medsonic Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LOTTERY WILL PAY DISPUTED JACKPOT
description: Virginia State Lottery officials said today that an Australian syndicate had broken the game's rules in the course of buying five million tickets in 72 hours, but that the group could still collect the $27 million jackpot.

title: WestAir Holding reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Sports of The Times; The Rangers' Political Insurance
description: THERE will not be a hockey strike. The Rangers will reach the Stanley Cup final. Remember, you read it here first. The reason the players will not go on strike and the Rangers will not fold is because that would work to the best interests of the Democrats, and everybody knows they haven't gotten anything right since the bicentennial.

title: Bill Clinton, in Black and White
description: Of all the numbers pouring forth from Super Tuesday, an exemplary one stands out. While winning half the total Democratic vote in Florida, Bill Clinton, white Southerner, won approximately 75 percent of the black vote.

title: Clary Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $ 30,000 for the quarter and income of $ 378,000, or 21 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $ 50,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 340,000, or 19 cents a share, for the year.c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 413,000 and $ 747,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: WorldCorp Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included a $ 6 million gain on the acquisition of debt.c-Net loss

title: Nixon's 'Save Russia' Memo: Bush Feels the Sting
description: By warning that the United States has provided "pathetically" insufficient assistance to Russia, former President Richard M. Nixon has stung the Bush Administration and focused attention on an issue that the Administration and Congress have been hesitating to address for months.

title: Staples Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $ 46,000 in the quarter and $ 1.2 million, or 7 cents a share, in the year, from utilization of net operating loss carryforwards.c-After extraordinary credits of $ 97,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 1,545,000, or 10 cents a share, in the year, from utilization of net operating loss carryforwards.Year-ago periods' income from continuing operations included a non-recurring charge of $ 2,053,000 related to the acquisition of lease rights.

title: Senior U.S. Officials Assail Lone-Superpower Policy
description: Senior White House and State Department officials have harshly criticized a draft Pentagon policy statement that asserts that America's mission in the post-cold-war era will be to prevent any collection of friendly or unfriendly nations from competing with the United States for superpower status.

title: A University Provost Is Named at Harvard
description: The president of Harvard University, Neil L. Rudenstine, has appointed a provost to oversee academic planning and fund-raising for the university's 11 schools, fulfilling a promise he made when he became president last July.

title:
BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
German Overhaul Is Led by Phones

Fax Broadcast, $5 a month, allows messages to be sent to several locations at once.

title: Voter Turnout: Seven Early States
description: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN Correction: April 15, 1992, Wednesday Charts on March 11, March 13 and March 26 giving voter turnout and votes cast in Presidential primaries omitted a cautionary label for the figures. All three charts also misstated the turnout for New Hampshire; the second and third charts also misstated that of Massachusetts. All the figures in the charts were preliminary and in some cases were based on estimates of voter registration. In New Hampshire, 62 percent of registered voters cast ballots on Feb. 18; in Massachusetts, 34.7 percent of registered voters cast ballots on March 10. A reader's letter, dated March 14 and delayed in reaching the editors, pointed out some of the errors and prompted a recheck of the figures. A corrected chart appears today on page A24.

title: Dell Computer Profit Rose 79% in Quarter

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Dow Up 15.87 in Busy and Volatile Trading
description: Stocks made modest gains in heavy trading yesterday, with bouts of program buying adding a fair amount of volatility. After being ahead as much as 30 points during the day, the Dow Jones industrial average gave half of that back to end at 3,230.99, up 15.87.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Tocchet Paces Penguins Rick Tocchet scored twice late in the first period and Joey Mullen got his 40th goal of the season last night in the Pittsburgh Penguins' 5-2 home-ice victory over the Calgary Flames. (AP) Blues 5, North Stars 2: Brendan Shanahan scored twice, ending a five-game goal drought, and Brett Hull got his league-leading 67th as St. Louis defeated visiting Minnesota. Hull and Ron Wilson scored short-handed goals for the Blues. (AP) BIATHLON Kirchner Triumphs Marc Kirchner of Germany won the men's 20-kilometer World Cup event yesterday in Skrautval, Norway, while the unblemished shooting of Hildegunn Fossen of Norway gave her first place in the women's 7.5-kilometer sprint. Kirchner missed once to bring his first-place time to 1 hour 1 minute 52 seconds. Fossen won the women's sprint in 26.02 with no penalty laps, while Ann Briand of France finished .12 seconds behind despite two extra laps for missed targets. (AP) SKIING Guy Outclasses Rivals Fabrice Guy of France virtually clinched the men's Nordic combined yesterday in Trondheim, Norway, by outclassing his rivals in the jumping event. With his three jumps of 117, 107.5 and 122 meters in the event, he collected 227.5 points, almost 28 points ahead of Klaus Ofner of Austria and more than 30 points ahead of third-place Jari Mantila of Finland. Guy will start today's 20-kilometer cross-country race with an overwhelming time advantage of 4 minutes and 37 seconds over Ofner. (AP) YACHT RACING Stars & Stripes Mishap The 110-foot mast of Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes snapped and toppled into the Pacific Ocean off San Diego yesterday during a race with Bill Koch's yacht, America3. None of the 17 crew members aboard Stars & Stripes were injured. America3 was ahead at the second mark by 35 seconds. In the challengers' races, New Zealand and Japan won their races yesterday, assuring both teams a place in the semifinals later this month.

title: Vogue's Plans for Centennial: A Big Issue and a Big Party
description: THIS is the season for prominent New York institutions to boast about their ages. First, Brooke Astor celebrated her 90th birthday with a party for hundreds at the Seventh Regiment Armory. The Metropolitan Opera recently marked 25 years at Lincoln Center. Now Vogue, another New York staple, is celebrating its 100th anniversary with a record number of pages for its April issue, a hardcover book and a party at the New York Public Library.

title: Big East Tournament Tickets Go On Sale
description: Tickets to tomorrow night's opening round of the Big East Conference basketball tournament, made available as part of an unused student block distributed to member schools, will go on sale at 3 P.M. today at the Madison Square Garden box office.

title: Ailing Ito Withdraws From the World Finals
description: A lingering cold has knocked MIDORI ITOout of the world figure skating championships in Oakland, Calif., later this month. The absence of the Olympic silver medalist leaves KRISTI YAMAGUCHI of Fremont, Calif., the Olympic champion and defending world champion, as the overwhelming favorite, and two other Americans, NANCY KERRIGAN and TONYA HARDING, as strong medal contenders. Kerrigan was the bronze medalist in Albertville, France.

title: Review/Rock; U2 Restyled, With Props and a Nod to the Fringes

He was dressed in shiny black leather, wearing sunglasses, with his hair slicked back, and as he sang he smiled, preened, even pumped his hips with a leer. He looked like someone trying to play a rock star on Broadway.

description: The chills and fever that sent Mayor David N. Dinkins to the hospital were caused by diverticulitis, an inflamed abscess on the wall of his colon, his doctors said yesterday. They said the Mayor would remain on powerful intravenous antibiotics and away from City Hall for several days at least.

title: Critic's Notebook; Defendants Contend With Video
description: It is a trial by video of video. Some analysts of the case against the four Los Angeles police officers charged with beating Rodney G. King a year ago say no charges would have been brought if an amateur videoist had not pointed his camera out his window that night. All agree that the trial, which began last week and is being carried by Court Television, must center on a fragment of video tape. At issue, along with what the defendants did to Mr. King and why they did it, is how much truth lies in the stark image.

title: Harold H. Fisher, 92, a Lawyer Who Investigated Lindbergh Case
description: Harold H. Fisher, a special assistant to the New Jersey Attorney General in the Lindbergh baby murder trial and a partner in one of the state's leading law firms, died on Friday at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, N.J. He was 92 years old and lived in Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: Colombian Accused as Drug Figure Draws 6-Year Term for Giving a False Name
description: Nearly six months after his arrest on a rainswept street in Queens, a young Colombian who authorities in South America say is a vicious drug-cartel assassin was sentenced yesterday to six years in prison for giving a false name to Federal officers as they surrounded him, guns drawn, at a corner pay phone.

title: Lakers Abuzz Over Triumph Against Knicks
description: When the final buzzer sounded, everyone in Madison Square Garden was staring at the referees, who had gathered in a huddle at midcourt. If Xavier McDaniel's 20-footer had beaten the buzzer, a sensational game was going into overtime. If McDaniel's shot was ruled late, the Knicks would lose.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the Democratic Presidential campaign in Dade County, Fla., described the Jewish vote there incorrectly. According to estimates by Democratic Party officials, Jewish voters represent more than half of the Democratic vote in the county, not half of the overall electorate.

title: The Potato, a Food For All Seasonings And Pocketbooks
description: POTATOES never go out of style, but they deserve more than being relegated to the side. They should be right up there with pasta and risotto: centerpieces, main dishes, a total experience. They're fast, they're packed with vitamins, they're cheap, and they're efficient carriers for all of the world's truly great condiments: butter, cream, rosemary and ketchup.

title: Public & Private; Marking Time
description: Prisoner 81-G-98 is reading A. N. Wilson's biography of Trollope. "What a piece of scholarship!" she says in a letter, which might just as well apply to her life at Bedford Hills Correctional Facility. During the course of a single year, she reads many periodicals as well as biographies of Queen Victoria, Tolstoy and Lyndon Johnson and some Dostoyevsky, Gogol and Eudora Welty.

The hosts for the concert, called "Bernstein," are to be Betty Comden and Adolph Green. The program, which is to benefit the chorus's AIDS Outreach Program, includes excerpts from Bernstein's Mass, "Candide" and "West Side Story" and other selections. Gary Miller conducts. Tickets are $10 to $50. Information: (212) 247-7800.

The soloists are to include Patrick Romano as the Evangelist, Eric Johnson as Jesus and Charles Robert Stephens as Pontius Pilate. Arias are to be sung by Susanne Peck, soprano; Alexandra Montano, alto; Tom Allen, tenor, and Kevin Deas, bass-baritone. Tickets are $12 in advance or $15 at the door. Information: (212) 254-8553.

description: Throughout his childhood in the Bronx, the constraints of climate and economics left Bobby Bonilla wildly hungry for more baseball. And so it was more just the desire to play than to succeed spectacularly that Bonilla's start in professional baseball, late and unremarkable as it was, satisfied most.

description: Salvatore Gravano's dramatic description of the murder of Paul Castellano was roundly ridiculed by John Gotti's lawyer yesterday on the fourth day of tenacious cross-examination.
