Edison, N.J. 205,000 106 Mount Pleasant Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 26-year-old split level; 2-zone heat, full basement; taxes $3,224.

title: On Her Toes
description: As Katherine Dunham weakens physically during her fast to protest the treatment of Haitian refugees, her spirit dances on. Miss Dunham, one of the pioneers of American modern dance, has subsisted on juice, tea and water for six weeks now at her home in East St. Louis, Ill., and says she will go on until the Bush Administration admits Haitians as political refugees. "The lives of those people who half drown in those little boats are being equated to animals," she said in an interview last weekend. "It means I have to declare out-and-out war." She has been advised on fasting by Dick Gregory, and has had telephone conversations with the deposed Haitian President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who is scheduled to visit her tomorrow. The 82-year-old Miss Dunham, who has a home in Haiti, has rejected Mr. Aristide's past advice to curtail her fast. "Even though I'm losing my voice and feeling a little tired, I can't stop fasting until there has been some resolution in Haiti," she said.

title:
COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
It's Duke, Carolina Again for Title Role
description: So it has come down to this. Again.

title: So Young, So Good, So Popular
description: EDNA ST. VINCENT MILLAY: SELECTED POEMS The Centenary Edition. Edited by Colin Falck. 162 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $18.

title: In Defense of the City Health Care Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 12 about the use of computers to make travel arrangements referred incorrectly to a service that provides overnight delivery of airline tickets. The service, called Quiktix, is offered by Prodigy Information Services, not Compuserve. A similar overnight service on the Compuserve network is called AA Online.

title: Theater Package In Ontario
description: Playgoers visiting two of Canada's leading theatrical events, the Stratford Festival in Stratford and the Shaw Festival in Niagara-on-the-Lake, can save money on accommodations under a new package plan called the Stratford and Shaw Midweek Getaway. The two festivals are about 100 miles apart in Ontario. Driving from one to the other takes about two hours, passing through Mennonite farm country near Stratford and vineyards and orchards near Niagara-on-the-Lake.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: On the Road; Brown's Campaign Is Using Volunteers to Put Chaos in Motion
description: Like the White Rabbit in "Alice in Wonderland," Edmund G. Brown Jr. and his campaign were behind schedule in Miami recently. But Mr. Brown was not crying, "I'm late, I'm late." Instead, he was chanting to the volunteer who was driving him: "Go. Go. Go. Get in there. Get in there."

title: WHEN MEN HIT WOMEN
description: Jan Hoffman's article "When Men Hit Women" (Feb. 16) hit me hard. In the end, it came down to the final paragraph: "Ellen Pence's advice to women in battering relationships is simply this: Leave." I was an abused wife for 10 years, until I finally got the courage to leave my husband last spring. While Pence's advice is entirely appropriate -- because men who abuse their women will not change -- it's never as easy as all that. For 10 years, I didn't even identify myself as a battered wife. I was desperately trying to fix something I believed in, my marriage, and to help someone I loved, my husband. In the early days, I cried to friends and they offered to come get me, but I always said no.

title:
CELEBRATING;
Parks, Gardens, Fairways: It's Easy to Be Green
description: THE Presidential candidates may be slugging it out on the issue of health care, but so far, no one on the campaign trail has put forth a remedy for the vernal equinox. Just try to find a private insurance carrier that includes spring fever in its coverage.

title: Leaning on the Left
description: ANTI-AMERICANISM

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DR. HARRY S. DWECK;
Trying to Keep Vulnerable Babies Alive
description: IN May the County Medical Center in Valhalla celebrates the 10th anniversary of the special unit for newborns with serious problems. In the last decade, the 30-bed unit for babies and mothers has cared for about 6,000 babies from the Hudson Valley region, many of whom were premature, some of whom had no chance for survival and others who would not have survived without the high-tech care the unit provides.

title: A Father Figure Leads Nine Children Into 'Four Baboons'
description: Sir Peter Hall has spent a lifetime in the theater directing legendary actors. So who could top Gielgud, Richardson and Redgrave? How about the nine "freewheeling" children in John Guare's "Four Baboons Adoring the Sun," opening Wednesday at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center?

title: Critical Of Critique
description: To the Editor:

title: VIDEO
description: March

title: California Republicans Ready for Civil War
description: Barring a political miracle, President Bush will have long since nailed down the Republican Presidential nomination by the time the big California primary rolls around on June 2. Nevertheless, the primary promises an emotional battle for the heart and soul of Republicanism in the largest state. It could also bring an early preview of the 1996 Republican Presidential sweepstakes.

title: Environmental Advocates Vie For Financing In Direct Pleas
description: FOUR major environmental-advocacy organizations on the Island are locked in a battle, vying for money from residents as they seek to impress them with the importance of protecting natural resources.

title: Holli Williams and Robert Ehrlich Are Married
description: Holli Michele Williams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Williams of Woodmere, L.I., was married in New York last evening to Robert Ehrlich, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Ehrlich of Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Abraham Weisman officiated at the Pierre.

title: Hiding Behind the Antidumping Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Here's the Way To Stop Fighting
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: East European Antiquities Shed Light on a Hidden World
description: Eastern Europe's impact in antiquity on the continent's culture has gone unrecognized largely because so little has been known about the region. During World War II and later under the Communists, it was off-limits to American and Western European scholars. But barriers have fallen, and new discoveries are being made.

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: Men's Fashions: Magazine Part 2 Reports in this issue include:

title: Pursuing Science, But Not Competition
description: IN a laboratory that carries about it the unmistakable metallic aroma of chemicals and has an abundance of glass beakers, petri dishes and pipettes arranged in an order fathomable only to the initiated, Mark Melkonian and Ying Taur stare intently at a small rectangle of what looks like blue Jell-O as they jot down observations in a notebook.

title: Is Japan Out to Get Us?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Composer Craves Respect
description: The case of the English Minimalist and soundtrack composer Michael Nyman is a strange one, stranger even than that of most marginal American composers. Lots of people have heard his music, maybe without quite knowing or caring. Enough of them have cared so that his London concerts are often full. Yet his bulging scrapbook contains few comments by the British classical-music press, which has apparently solved the Nyman "problem" by ignoring it, and him.

title: Man Shoots Attacker, Then Tries to Save Him
description: After being stabbed at least four times in a deserted subway station in Manhattan early yesterday, a 43-year-old court officer emptied his revolver at the man who had attacked him and then dragged the near-dead assailant off to find him help, the police said.

title: By Hong Kong Measure, 1997 Is Any Day Now
description: On an isolated concrete isle in Hong Kong's central business district stands the Bank of China building, a narrow, shimmering monolith that cuts a sharp, overbearing image against the sky as it looms over the nearby residence of the British-appointed Governor, Lord Wilson.

title: Events Calendar In the Caribbean
description: Windsurfers from many countries are expected to take part in the sixth annual ARUBA Hi-Winds Pro-Am Windsurfing Competition on Eagle Beach in Aruba from May 26 to June 6. A total of $100,000 in prizes will be awarded during the event, in which amateurs will compete the first week and professionals the second. The winner of a Round the Isle race will collect $20,000. Information: (800) 862-7822.

title: Noted with Pleasure
description: The Third Kiss

title: FILM
description: March

title: Rates Are Up, And Bonds Look Good
description: The economy is growing, and bond prices always fall when that happens. So sell bonds.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: At this very moment, there are thousands of engaged and soon-to-be-engaged couples who think their future mates are just about perfect -- just about. Sure, there are a few small things that grate a little, that could be changed; but they're nothing that can't be dealt with.

title: Boy's Dream Becomes Man's Pain
description: FOR five months Sylvester Williams has lived with four other inmates in a dormitory room at the Connecticut Correctional Center on Whalley Avenue in New Haven. As the oldest in the room, he said, he often counsels the others, telling them that selling or using drugs is not the answer. A good, solid education, he reminds them, is the only thing that matters. "But then," he said, "they look at me as if to say: 'Hey, look at what you had, and look at you now. So who are you to be talking anyway?' "

title:
FORUM;
The Glorious Oversight Revolution
description: This week, the Securities and Exchange Commission will convene an unusual conference in Washington, to hear analysis and suggestions for reform of the corporate governance process. The conference is part of an S.E.C. review that has generated reform proposals in the past 12 months in everything from regulation of investor communications to the reporting of executive compensation.

title: Preventing the Next Saddam Hussein
description: It's no secret that the nations now scrambling to destroy Iraq's nuclear program, including the U.S., helped supply Baghdad with the tools to build the bomb. Legislation now before Congress could keep that from happening again. And President Bush? He's against it.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Weston
description: "WESTON is the ultimate hometown," said Patricia Heifetz, who recently sold The Weston Forum, a weekly newspaper she started in 1970.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Denver; A Composer's Music Is a Message to Students
description: To the music world, David Amram is a prolific American composer, but to music and dance students at the University of Denver here, he is known as the encourager in residence.

title: Senate's Tax Bill Wraps Up a Bouquet of Trial Balloons
description: The tax bill the Senate passed Friday night is not just a $300 credit for children, a 36 percent rate for the affluent or a new set of rates for capital gains taxes. Nor is it merely legislation intended to make health insurance much more widely available, especially to workers in small businesses.

title: Waiting for the Moonbow
description: LIKE the Colossus at Rhodes, a vast moonlit rainbow straddles Kentucky's Cumberland Falls, bulging against the January night sky. Drawing its power from the full moon overhead, the great spectral arch lases a thousand colors into the eyes of its beholders, who march in dead tympanic rhythm toward the river gorge cliff.

title: Liesl Corbin Has Wedding
description: Elizabeth Merrick Corbin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Kellogg Corbin 3d of New Vernon, N.J., was married there yesterday to Stephen Chandler Rexford Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rexford of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Dr. George E. Chorba performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Much Ado About Shakespeare in Washington
description: History likes dates and this city likes its history. So Monday, March 2, 1992, will probably go down as the day the Shakespeare Theater came of age.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: STEVEN WEINBERG;
Science Education Is Process, Not Memory
description: SEVERAL recent indicators, like declining scores on science achievement exams and national assessments of educational progress, suggest that American students' interest in science has been diminishing. Steven Weinberg, president of the Connecticut chapter of Educators for Responsible Science, said that some authorities estimate that by 2000 the United States will face a shortage of 700,000 scientists, engineers and health-care workers.

title: Jill Rogers To Wed in May
description: Jill Rogers, a theatrical publicist in London, and Joseph Warren Davis, an actor based in New York, are engaged to be married in May.

title: Car Ferry Plan Fails in Seattle
description: The Bermuda-based Sea Containers has dropped its plan to operate car ferry service between downtown Seattle and Victoria, British Columbia, this year. The company said that it had been unable to resolve various issues with the British Columbia Government, the Canadian Coast Guard, Canadian Customs and the Port of Seattle. It complained that it had been asked to pay rent at the Seattle and Victoria terminals far higher than that paid by the Stena Line, which ran a car ferry on the route until November 1990, and that it faced a pilotage fee not levied on other vessels.

title: A Reluctant Rejection On Davids Island
description: WHEN the City Council decided last week to sever the contract that gave Xanadu Properties Associates exclusive rights to build a luxury residential colony on Davids Island, the developer had gone as far as he could go, he said, in reducing the density of the project.

title: OUTINGS
description: Here is a sampling of outings in the New York metropolitan region during the spring season. Dates and times are subject to change. Today

title: Data Update
Meg Crone Is to Wed C. M. Ramsden
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Crone of Charleston, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Meaghan Crone to Christopher McLean Ramsden, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Ramsden of Barrington, R.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Canada Braces for a Spring Without Zing
description: It has been 52 years since the New York Rangers last won the Stanley Cup and they can easily dredge up at least that many excuses. Now, much to their everlasting chagrin, they could end up with one more.

title:
Style Makers;
Norman Bukofzer, Bartender
description: One evening a table of businesswomen at the Jockey Club in Manhattan noticed the Irish actor Liam Neeson at the bar. What to do? Call on Norman Bukofzer, the genial bartender-psychiatrist-matchmaker who presides at the club. Within seconds, Mr. Neeson was sharing a drink with his fans.

title: Review/Rap; Disposable Heroes of Hiphoprisy
description: The Disposable Heroes of Hiphoprisy aren't just a band -- they're a coalition. At C.B.G.B. on Wednesday night, the group included a rapper who sometimes sang, a drummer, a guitarist with jazz leanings, a keyboardist who also slammed metal on metal like an industrial rocker, and an offstage crew that played backup tapes and projected supertitles above the stage.

title: No Sound Bites Here
description: 'TELL YOU A STORY," Brian Lamb says. It is employee-orientation week at the Cable Satellite Public Affairs Network, and the company's silver-haired chief is holding court before a group of fresh-faced newcomers, with tales of his early days in Washington. Just out of the Navy in the late 1960's, Lamb found his way to a black Baptist church to see Stokely Carmichael, the fiery civil rights activist.

title: A Sweet Pleasure From New Orleans: The Praline
description: PRALINES, those homely, old-fashioned New Orleans candies, are not exactly making a comeback. They never left town. Defying all warnings about the perils of sugar and the fat content of nuts, the confections that resemble a mud pie with pebbles are more popular than ever.

title: Corrections
description: A styling credit today on page 38 of Men's Fashions of The Times, part 2 of The Times Magazine, with an article about Miami, omits the name of a hair stylist. He is Ric Pipino of Pipino-Buccheri Salon.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Issues; The New, Volatile Politics of Welfare
description: Sixteen years after Ronald Reagan transformed the "welfare queen" into a weapon of class warfare in his first try at the Presidency, candidates of both parties have been emboldened by the recession to make welfare a seminal political issue.

title: Corrections
description: The Mutual Funds column last Sunday about shutdowns of new investment in some funds misstated the policy of the Oppenheimer Global Bio-Tech Fund on investment by existing shareholders. Shareholders may buy additional shares.

title: U.N. Peacekeeping Force Moves Into Yugoslavia
description: The first United Nations peacekeeping force to operate on the European mainland began settling into Sarajevo today, its commanders aware of the ethnic tensions among Bosnia's population of Slavic Muslims, Serbs and Croats and the risk they pose to one of the United Nations' most volatile operations ever.

title: Perspectives: West Orange; Home Builders Step Up Construction
description: OTHER builders around New Jersey may differ, but Sam M. Gershwin is betting on a pick-up in the home-buying market. He says the evidence is already in hand. It's nothing dramatic, but it's enough to lead the building company in which he is a partner to accelerate production.

title: Mutual Funds; A Steady March Into Funds
description: Individual investors are gradually increasing the proportion of stocks that they hold through mutual funds compared with what they own directly. This trend began in 1981 and has accelerated except for one minor slip after the 1987 stock market crash.

title: Picking Up The Pace On a Trend
description: MY friends Paula and Donald live in Brooklyn, in the Fort Hamilton section to be exact. Like a lot of people, they are in the market for a new vehicle and they've talked about the search. Like a lot of people too, they are looking not for an automobile but for a truck.

title: Merce Cunningham, Explorer and Anarchist
description: During "Place," a dance work he created in 1966 and performed for several years, Merce Cunningham would pop into a plastic sack and propel himself across the stage like a wet fish on dry land.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Here is a sampling of antique shows in the New York metropolitan region this spring. Dates and times are subject to change. Today

title: Making Faces
description: JULIEN D'YS SOUNDS A BIT PEEVISH -- albeit charming -- as he discusses the Paris ready-to-wear shows about to take place. "People always want something new," he says with a sigh. "But it is so difficult to do every season."

title: A Familiar Final: Georgetown Plays Syracuse
description: After weeks of unimaginable peaks and valleys, after the finish of a St. John's-Georgetown semifinal that seemed as if it would never end, the Big East's madcap 13th season has at long last been distilled to. . . .

title: Miss Meyer Engaged
description: Mrs. Richard G. Hewitt and Theodore R. Meyer, both of New York, have announced July wedding plans for their daughter Elizabeth Jane Meyer and Charles Bennett Gadon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Gadon of Cranston, R.I. Miss Meyer, 32 years old, is a vice president with U.S. Auction, a real-estate auction concern in Stamford, Conn. She graduated from Johns Hopkins University and received a master's degree in business management from Columbia University. Mr. Gadon, 35, is the engineering and systems manager for Providence Metallizing Company, a finishing concern in Pawtucket, R.I. He graduated from Northeastern University.

title: Q and A
description: Reduction of Shares Question: I bought a co-op apartment in 1983. At the closing I learned that I was acquiring 149 shares instead of the 153 shares listed in the prospectus. The reason for the discrepancy was that the apartment's former tenant shareholder, who also owned a neighboring unit, had moved a dividing wall, thereby reducing my space by about 24 square feet. This change was noted in a resolution voted on by the co-op's board of directors. I was issued a revised proprietary lease stating that 149 shares were assigned to my apartment.

title: POSTING: Guardian Life Grows; Faithful to Union Square
description: The Guardian Life Insurance Company of America long ago outgrew its 20-story home office, a landmark at 201 Park Avenue South at 17th Street. But it won't leave its Union Square neighborhood.

title: With an N.C.A.A. Title in Hand, Trapp Aims Higher
description: Ask James Trapp whether his chances of making the United States Olympic team are better in the 100 meters or 200 meters, and he says, "I think my chances are best in both."

title: Blanche Kwas Engaged to Wed P. J. Johnson Jr.
description: May wedding plans have been announced for Blanche Kwas, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tone Kwas of Woodbury, L.I. , and Peter James Johnson Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson of New York.

title: I Slod Clothes In the Naked City
description: Several years ago, while adjusting to the initial surprise that a word processor only made my fledgling writing attempts look neater, not more intelligent, two friends of mine who own a Chelsea men's store offered me a job. Now, some people were born to sell clothes, and some, like me, were simply too clumsy to become waiters. I told them I didn't think I had the talent or the temperament. I certainly had no intention of buying into the adage that "the customer is always right," nor could I see myself feeling sorry for the frantic man who comes in five minutes before I'm supposed to go home, or the fool who swears he didn't launder the rayon shirt by accident. But I was broke, so I accepted the offer. And my bosses/friends were patient, even after hearing my first sales pitch: "What's your problem?" They simply pointed out that good writers had keen ears and watchful eyes, and what better opportunity to hone my powers of observation than while hawking suits and ties?

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HAMILTON FISH Memoir of an American Patriot. By Hamilton Fish. Regnery Gateway, $19.95.

title: Rangers Face the Blues and Other Woes
description: Coach Roger Neilson had a lot on his mind tonight, beginning but not ending with Brett Hull.

title: At Work; Romanians Start From Scratch
description: Of all the images transmitted to the West during the disintegration of Communism in Eastern Europe, perhaps none were as searing as those from the orphanages and hospitals of Romania after the fall of Nicolae Ceausescu.

title: We Could All Learn a Thing or Two From the Chimpanzees
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Connelly, Teacher, Wed
description: Jennifer Kathleen Connelly, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Terrence R. Connelly of New York, was married yesterday to Charles Talcott Enders, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony T. Enders of New York. The Rev. John W. Lennon, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Turning Back the Clock to Reinvent the Mall
description: Welcome to the latest edition of McArchitecture. Like a slugger at the age of 35, or a dog at 9, a shopping mall has pretty much had it by age 25. But with more malls passing this milestone and no money to build new ones, the name of the architectural game has become "asset enhancement." Translation: reinventing and repackaging old malls.

title:
FORUM;
Unleash America's Banks
description: Many American policy makers blame Japan for causing the nation's economic difficulties. Some politicians are now pushing hard to adopt anti-Japanese protectionist measures. The trade imbalance, however, is only a symptom of deep industrial problems that require serious attention.

title: A Picture Is Worth a Zillion Bits
description: MAPPING THE NEXT MILLENNIUM

title: The Executive Computer; Picking the Right Microprocessor Grows More Complex
description: The world of microprocessors has changed dramatically, moving from a linear path based on power to a diversity of specialized chips. As chips advance along many different paths simultaneously, the resulting hubbub could leave customers immersed in a great deal of confusion.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-15 IRAQ HUNTS SHIITE REBELS

title: Alicia Galanter Marries in England
description: Alicia Anderson Galanter, a daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Eugene Galanter of New York, was married yesterday to Roland Dominic Walton, a son of John Walton of Radlett, Hertfordshire, England, and Countess Annette d'Exea Walton of Cambridge, England. The Rev. Paul Nelson performed the Church of England ceremony at St. Nicholas Church in Kenilworth, Warwickshire, England.

title:
Style Makers;
Cynthia Hadesman, Designer and Boutique Owner
description: Cynthia Hadesman's Chicago shop, Krivoy, is like a fairy kingdom of clothing, hats and antique accessories. Moss-colored dresses have hand-sewn leaves blowing softly down the shoulders. Tiny plaid jackets and pants for children, with matching caps, seem shaped for elves. Satin evening slippers curl up discreetly at their pointed toes as if ready for an evening with Scheherazade.

title:
ART;
Words Join Images in Yale Show
description: THE career of Peter Nadin straddles the conventional and the unconventional, representation and abstraction with amazing assurance. The 38-year-old British-born painter, who has lived and worked in New York City since the mid-1970's, specializes in still lifes and views out the window. But above that comfort level, his painting is a piling on of devices and painterly techniques that makes one realize that one of his favorite images, the Tower of Babel, perfectly reflects his intentions.

title: A New Jolt for Mets: All 3 Players Identified
description: Dwight Gooden, Vince Coleman and Daryl Boston are the three Mets under investigation by the Port St. Lucie Police Department in a rape complaint filed by a woman here March 3, according to a lawyer familiar with the investigation.

title: Networking; Getting It Under Control
description: The explosion in the number, size and complexity of networks makes managing them rough. "We've got several thousand PC's and several hundred Macs talking to 75 LAN servers and I.B.M. mainframes and DEC minis," said Dan Kohner, manager of network services at the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center at the University of Texas. "Managing it all keeps me up nights."

title: Business Diary/March 8-13
description: COMPANIES The F.C.C. Moves to Free the Airwaves -- but for Whom?

title: Cycle of Seasons Brings Back Season for Cycling
description: LIKE all seasons, spring brings special pleasures to New York: Flower boxes. Allergies. And the renewed opportunity for scores of cyclists to be driven from the road by lethally crazed cabdrivers looking for a good time between fares.

title: Replay and Labor Lead Issues at N.F.L. Talks
description: As the National Football League owners gather in Phoenix today for their annual meeting, it appears that instant replay will once again be approved but that hopes of solving the league's labor mess remain slim.

title: Fighting for Rights
description: A PEOPLE'S CHARTER The Pursuit of Rights in America. By James MacGregor Burns and Stewart Burns. 577 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primaries; Clinton's Rivals Seek Midwest Toehold
description: The Democratic Presidential campaign focused on the critical primaries of the industrial Midwest this weekend, with Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas running strongly in Illinois but with former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California trying to trip him up in the more uncertain political terrain of Michigan.

title: A New Tune For Radio: Hard Times
description: Though a dedicated optimist, Randall Harris looks out from his tiny AM radio station in Sarasota, Fla., and periodically wonders whether survival is possible. When his father bought WSPB two years ago to air classical music, the station was so unprofitable that its former owner had turned off the transmitter. Since then, at least two other stations in the city have "gone dark," in industry jargon, and two more broadcast on and off as their owners search for successful formats.

title: Recession Boosts Ranks of Volunteers
description: BRENDA SHICK of Rye Brook is a founder of Corporate Outreach, which organizes employees of Westchester corporations for volunteer projects. A year ago, however, she lost her job with Citibank.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Penn State; Students Tee Off New Class Option For Golf Managers
description: When Matt Jester signed up for his college major, he needed to present an application form, his academic record -- and his golf handicap.

title:
WHAT'S DOING IN;
Singapore
description: Some years ago, officials at Singapore's Tourist Promotion Board noticed that most visitors found little to keep them on the island for longer than three days. One of the main problems was that rapid development coupled with an almost fanatic preoccupation with cleanliness and order had leeched the city of the exotic atmosphere that tourists flew to Asia to find. Large parts of the city looked like a tropical version of any one of the tens of indistinguishable midsized cities spread across North America and Europe.

title: THE PROS HDF>hHED,6,39,1; The Cyclone Man and Others Who Bring You Spring
description: AH, spring! Finally, the sky glistens and balmy breezes arrive. Buds appear on the trees, eager to unfurl into leaves. There are the tootling birds, the scrabbling squirrels, the crocuses. You walk down the sidewalk and spy dead stoves, ironed-out ironing boards and grungy carpeting overcome by cat hair.

title: Commercial Property: The Port Authority and Starrett Lehigh Buildings; For 2 Huge Relics, Different Futures
description: TWO 1930's red-brick structures -- relics of Manhattan's industrial past, when giant warehouses were in great demand -- dominate their localities.

title: Home Away From No Home in Trenton
description: AT 5 P.M. precisely, just as dusk settled around a collection of grimy gray buildings on Carroll Street in downtown Trenton, the cafeteria line inside the Rescue Mission began to move.

title: Miami Vice
description: Ever hear the story about the airline pilot who was murdered with his own gun by his wife's jealous lover?

title: G. C. Whitney to Wed Ms. Douwes
description: Francoise W. Douwes of Abington, Pa., has announced the engagement of her daughter Francine Caroline Douwes to Gifford Cochran Whitney, a son of Alexandra E. Whitney of New York and the late Harry P. Whitney. A May wedding is planned.

title: Coins
description: Tokens In Lieu of Change Among a host of coins being auctioned later this month is a rare and interesting example of the "Hard Luck" tokens of the early-19th century. This particular one is called the "Am I Not a Man & a Brother" token, a title taken from the inscription on the obverse.

title: Primaries Demonstrate Democracy at Work; Opposition Leader
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on March 1 about the return of war booty misidentified the evangelist depicted in a 10th-century Gospel. It was St. Matthew, not St. Luke.

title: Answering His Accuser
description: To the Editor:

title: Social Events
description: Aiding Young Opera Singers

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ARDSLEY AUTO AUCTION

title: It's Not Easy Being a WASP
description: FALSE GODS

title: Brazil's Pristine Playground
description: PAMPERED by the luxury of choosing among 4,600 miles of South Atlantic coastline, Brazilian beach connoisseurs increasingly choose Praia do Forte, a pastoral, seven-mile stretch of white sand, blue water and coconut palms.

title: Dollar Is Up Against the Yen
William Finkelstein Loves a Good Divorce
description: The year was 1985. A 33-year old novice attorney and aspiring writer -- named William M. Finkelstein was coming to grips with practicing law in New York. As befit a first-year lawyer, he handled mainly routine matters: wills, estates, research for more experienced litigators, low-profile divorce cases. Then one day, analyzing yet another marriage dissolution, he came to a startling conclusion: he had a rare chance to change the very nature of New York State divorce law. "It involved something called 'The Theory of Negative Contribution,' " recalls Mr. Finkelstein.

title: A School Official Sacrifices His Job to Soften Budget Cuts
description: ALTHOUGH Thomas A. Mulvihill is something of a hero in Ridgefield, he is not safe from being the butt of a joke. "A friend called me and asked if Mother Teresa was there," said Mr. Mulvihill, the assistant superintendent of the Ridgefield public schools.

title: INSIDE
description: New Strain to U.S.-Israel Ties

title: Haitians Return to Deepening Misery
description: When the Coast Guard cutter Dependable berthed here this morning amid a collection of rusty freighters and listing wrecks, the marines aboard joined local photographers in crowding the gangway to snap pictures of the thin and threadbare Haitians who are expected to be among the last of the thousands forcibly returned to their country.

title: Cuttings; Appreciating Nature, and Seeing Civilization, Too
description: William Howard Adams sat on the porch of his log house and stared out at the field that rolled right up to the step. It was still the yellow-brown of winter, though soon it would be a wash of green.

title: Streetscapes: 80 Wooster Street; The Irascible 'Father' of SoHo
description: EVEN in the last quarter century of profound change, no neighborhood in Manhattan has been as utterly transformed as SoHo. From a backwater of decrepit lofts and low-tech industry, it has emerged as an expensive neighborhood of "spaces" shown proudly in magazines like Architectural Digest.

title: Why Men Hate to Dress
description: A young man laces up a pair of brown suede bucks by Gianni Versace in Barneys New York's shoe department. He stands up, wiggles his toes, bounces up and down, walks about a bit, looks in the mirror, looks at the bottom of one shoe, then turns to his female companion and says, "It's up to you. What do you think?"

title: As the World Turns, U.S. Policy Stands Still
description: It is hard to put an exact date on it but sometime over the summer, foreign policy just vanished from the American political debate, as though it were some fad that went out of style.

title: Ann Czerwonka To Wed in May
description: Mrs. Henry V. Czerwonka of Glastonbury, Conn., has announced May wedding plans for her daughter Ann Cassidy Czerwonka and Thomas Moore Heller, a son of Frederick Heller of Sonoita, Ariz., and the late Catherine Flynn. Miss Czerwonka is also a daughter of the late Mr. Czerwonka.

title: Turkey Digs Through Quake's Debris
description: Aftershocks rippled through eastern Turkey today, and rescuers dug in the rubble for survivors after a powerful earthquake that may have killed more than 600 people.

title:
FOOD;
Behind French Doors
description: THE FIRST TIME I VISITED PARIS was a disaster. The City of Light was gray and rainy, the steaks were thin and mean and so, it seemed, was everybody I met. It was a typical encounter between Paris and anything or anyone not of Paris. But I was too young and stupid to know that. I thought the snubbing was personal. Two decades later, I better understand the protectionism that prompts Parisians to hide their best brasseries in dreary little cul de sacs, their best bakeries on unfindable streets and the best of their improvisational cooking in private homes.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: 1959By Thulani Davis.Grove Weidenfeld, $19.95.

title: Orangemen And Edwards Get in Gear
description: Michael Edwards?

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans; Buchanan's Wife Stays in Step With a Smile but Seldom a Word
description: At rallies she sits demurely by her husband's side, her round face frozen in a smile, waiting for the cue that will give her her only public role in the campaign.

title: WHEN MEN HIT WOMEN
description: Hoffman's article brought back painful memories of interning at a domestic-violence counseling center. From the therapist's point of view, treating families involved in domestic abuse can be frustrating and exhausting. Any threat to the relationship between the abusive spouse and the victim, namely therapy, is quickly thwarted. Holding on to one's spouse is equivalent to staying attached to one's primary relationship with the mother (however abusive she was). Therefore, leaving one's spouse is extremely difficult and threatening to one's sense of being. This concept holds true for both the batterer and the victim. NAN MILLER Flushing, Queens

title: Police, Disenchanted With Radar, Track Speeders With Lasers
description: THE driver of the beat-up Chrysler Cordoba was unaware that she was being observed by police officers as she sped along the River Moody Overpass in Hartford. But standing near an intersection a quarter-mile from the car, Officer Anthony Santos of the Hartford police had spotted the car in the scope of his laser speed gun and squeezed the trigger to determine its speed in less than a second.

title: Fitzpatrick Stymies LaFontaine And Sabres
description: Solid goaltending by Mark Fitzpatrick spoiled Pat LaFontaine's first visit to Nassau Coliseum since he was traded to Buffalo in October as the Islanders beat the Sabres, 4-1, this afternoon.

title: Results Plus
description: SKIING Mahrer Wins Downhill in Aspen Daniel Mahrer of Switzerland capped a brilliant two weeks of racing yesterday by capturing the final men's World Cup downhill ski race this season, in Aspen, Colo. Mahrer, with two victories and a second-place finish in the three downhills held this month, fought his way through tight turns on the bottom half of the course and beat his teammate William Besse by 33 one-hundredths of a second. The 30-year-old Mahrer was timed in 1 minute 41.91 seconds.(AP)

title: No Balance? No Problem!
description: A voter could wind up in trouble with the law for treating a checking account the way some politicians treated theirs in a bank run by the House of Representatives for its members. After audits last year showed that most members sometimes overdrew their accounts and some members did so routinely, House Democrats began looking for a way to contain the damage. They hoped to get away with simply closing the bank and making public the names of the two dozen worst abusers of a system that allowed members to write insufficiently funded checks without penalty or interest.

title: By Default
description: "It's time to see what a woman can do," said Jack Finn, an old Jersey City Democratic hand, as Marilyn Roman became the first woman Mayor of New Jersey's second largest city last week. Mrs. Roman rose to office not because of any savvy campaigning, but rather because she was, um, there. She had been City Council president when Mayor Gerald McCann was forced out, convicted on Federal fraud charges, making her acting Mayor. A great deal of Council bickering ensued over who would be named interim Mayor. Last Thursday, after a month in which the eight members of the Council were unable to assemble the five votes needed to elect any of 13 candidates, they ceded the job to her. The 56-year-old Mayor, who will serve until a special election in November or until the Council re-organizes, possibly in July, has taken a leave of absence from her job as director of the Education-Business Alliance for the city's Board of Education. She'll remain as City Council president.

title: Students Join Tribute to Jim Henson
description: HOW do you get to Avery Fisher Hall? In Armonk these days it helps to be a flutist or drummer, attend either the middle school or high school here and, of course, practice, practice, practice.

title: All About/Telephone Features; Emboldened Phone Companies Are Pushing the Frills
description: Knock, knock. It's the Amway door-to-door sales representative. But along with the usual assortment of soaps and shampoos, some of these sales reps are now pitching Caller ID, which identifies the telephone number of an incoming call.

title: A June Wedding For Ms. Pitcher
description: Nina Pitcher of Castleton, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter Stephanie Margaret Pitcher to Daniel Martin Cohen, the son of Sue T. Cohen and Dr. Arnold R. Cohen of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Irish Pub Music
description: To the Editor: I was interested to read "A Hornpipe, a Reel and a Pint" about Irish music pubs (Travel, Dec. 29). My family and I spent a year in Northern Ireland as part of an academic exchange and we were much impressed by the Irish pubs. There is a different feeling in Irish pubs than in bars and lounges in the U.S. In Ireland they are community gathering spots. I see them as extensions of people's living rooms. They are warm, safe, congenial places to gather for conversation, music and company.

title: Suzanne Ellen Feldstein to Wed Roger Frankel
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Feldstein of New City, N.Y., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Suzanne Ellen Feldstein, and Roger H. Frankel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Frankel of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: A Few Things About Spring
description: For connoisseurs of the green season, ready to emerge from winter quarters, stretch a bit in the sun and get going again, here are some random facts:

title: Don't Upset the Chalice
description: A DRESSER OF SYCAMORE TREES

title: Hollywood Law: Whose Idea Is It, Anyway?
description: In the latest skirmish of the Hollywood plagiarism wars, a lawsuit filed in state court here alleges that the television producer Aaron Spelling stole an idea that H. W. Broido Jr., a merchandise marketer, pitched to him. Mr. Broido charges that Mr. Spelling used his idea as the basis for the hit Fox series "Beverly Hills, 90210."

title: Enlisting Patients to Fight Their Own Illness
description: MARY PLASKON sat among a group of cancer patients meditating to the sound of soft music and the serene, reassuring voice of a group leader.

title: Primaries Demonstrate Democracy at Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Camera
description: Most people probably don't know David Tenenbaum, but many may recall a photograph he took for The Associated Press at the 1980 Winter Olympic Games in Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PORTRAIT OF AN EYE Three Novels. By Kathy Acker. Pantheon, Paper, $15.

title: BILLS SEEK TO END LAWMAKERS' PERKS
description: Driving home on Friday from Capitol Hill to his district in southern New Jersey, Representative William J. Hughes heard caller after caller tell a radio talk show host how angry they were over the perquisites enjoyed by members of Congress.

title: Chess
description: Gary Kasparov of Russia, the world champion, is slowly but steadily increasing his lead in his confrontations with his archrival and compatriot Anatoly Karpov. In the most recent segment of their series, they drew their game in Reggio Emilia, an elite event in northern Italy that ended on Jan. 6. Then Kasparov defeated Karpov on Feb. 23 in round two of the elite Linares International Tournament in Spain.

title: Sunday Menu; Vegetable Stew, With a Kick on the Side
description: Zucchini and fennel are essential parts of this hearty vegetable stew and must not be overcooked. If they retain some of their crunch, they provide another texture to the dish, beyond the creamy lentils and the firm potatoes.

title: Pamela Foster Plans Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Carlton Foster of Wayland, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Marks Foster, to Stephen Alan Crystal, a son of Helene Crystal of New York and the late Jerome Crystal. An August wedding is planned.

title: DANCE
description: March 17 to 29

title: Shelley Rosen Weds Ira Taub
description: Shelley Rosen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Rosen of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday evening in New York to Ira Stuart Taub, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Taub of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi Bruce Block performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: A VOICE OF ONE'S OWN: Conversations With America's Writing Women, by Mickey Pearlman and Katherine Usher Henderson. (Houghton Mifflin, $8.95.) Interviews with 28 authors, ranging from Joyce Carol Oates to Amy Tan, illuminate how these women became writers and what shapes their work. In 1990, when the book was published as "Inter/View: Talks With America's Writing Women," our reviewer, Alexandra Johnson, noted that "the merit of this collection is how it charts the passages, often circuitous, in the complex life process that finally yields the literary product."

title: Deals and Discounts
description: CARIBBEAN RESORTS A number of resorts in Jamaica and St. Thomas have special air fares in connection with stays. On Jamaica, a round-trip air fare of $99 from New York is offered to travelers who stay seven nights at Couples, Grand Lido Negril or Jamaica, Jamaica, three resorts operated by Superclubs. The fare is available from Kennedy, Newark and Islip (L.I.) airports; various airlines are used. For a seven-night stay, rates at Couples start at $2,510 for two people sharing a double room through April 2; at Grand Lido, rates begin at $1,695 for each of two people sharing a double room through April 30, and at Jamaica, Jamaica, rates start at $1,350 for each of two sharing a room through April 2. All-inclusive rates include meals, wine, bar drinks, airport transfers, hotel taxes and sports activities. For more information, call Superclubs at (800) 858-8009.

title: Too Liberal to Live
description: THE PELICAN BRIEF By John Grisham. 371 pp. New York: Doubleday. $22.50.

title: Jobs and Protectionism Test Candidates' Creativity
description: Richard M. Nixon to the contrary notwithstanding, there is one foreign-policy issue that has caught the attention of candidates and voters this winter. Not aid to Russia or the future of NATO or relations with China, though; the issue is foreign trade, and what it does to jobs at home.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York SENATE

title: Super Tuesday II: High Stakes Again
description: The Democratic Presidential campaign focused on the critical primaries of the industrial Midwest coming Tuesday, with Bill Clinton running strongly in Illinois but with Paul E. Tsongas and Edmund G. Brown Jr. trying to trip him in the more uncertain political terrain of Michigan.

title: EVERYBODY'S SOMEBODY'S BABY
description: Kingsolver didn't have to go to Spain to find people who like children. She could have gone to the nearest firehouse. As a New York City firefighter, I have lifted my share of children into the seat of many a fire engine. There is something about the look on their faces when they put on that fire helmet and pretend they are racing down the street, sirens blaring. Even the most seasoned salt will sneak a wave to children as we drive around town. As Kingsolver said, the children of today are our future doctors, Presidents and even firefighters, and every child needs love. JOSEPH FARRELLY Staten Island

title: WHEN MEN HIT WOMEN
description: Hoffman states that "violence by women against men is usually in self-defense or retaliation, and is often less severe." Tell that to men like me who have been the victims of domestic violence. During my stormy four-year marriage, I was abused physically and emotionally by my wife. It was I who raised my hands in self-defense (but never in retaliation). When I finally admitted to myself that I was a battered husband, I decided to seek help and support.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FROM PURITANISM TO POSTMODERNISM A History of American Literature. By Richard Ruland and Malcolm Bradbury. Viking, $29.95.

title:
The Executive Life;
The Class Approach To a Perfect Party
description: Michael van C. Ault, 29, of New York and Palm Beach, has decided to gather a group of friends at Bistro ici on the Upper East Side of Manhattan for April Fools' Day. Like many sociable New Yorkers, Mr. Ault pores over his address book, carefully putting together the perfect mix of people for his parties. What sets Mr. Ault apart is that his address book runs to some 37,000 names.

title: ACCIDENTS OF HISTORY
description: It cannot be denied that the Yuquis are living more comfortably at Chimore with the missionaries. But is it really necessary to strip them of something as fundamental as their own names? Or to make them ashamed of their own bodies? In every way, the Yuquis have been made to feel that their life in the forest was not only irrelevant to their present life, but foolish. JILL KINGDON DEMPSEY New York, N.Y.

title: Miss Markham To Wed in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Sanford M. Markham of Falls Church, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Anne Markham, to Morgan Clarke McLanahan, a son of Mrs. Duer McLanahan of New York and the late Mr. McLanahan. A June wedding is planned.

title: No Generation Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Festive Days in Assisi, Town of St. Francis
description: "BREATHE the air of Assisi deeply," a Jesuit astronomer had said to me on a hot day south of Rome, when I told him where I was going for four days in early August. There was a hint of envy in his voice, and he left it to me to find out what he meant.

title:
DINING OUT;
An Exploration of North Indian Cuisine
description: JUST a few blocks from the Metro Park train station in Woodbridge is a dimly lighted Indian restaurant called Moghul. Although it's in a large shopping center in the Middlesex County community of Edison, it has some relatively exotic neighbors, including a store that sells ingredients for Indian food and a Japanese restaurant called Tokyo.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidate's Record; Unions Are Split on Backing Clinton
description: Workers in Michigan and Illinois, two big-labor states whose primaries on Tuesday may well decide the Democratic Presidential nomination, will find no definitive reading on Gov. Bill Clinton's labor record if they look toward his home state of Arkansas.

title: Yoko Ono, Anew
description: It was Yoko Ono's fortune and misfortune to marry John Lennon. Whatever claims revisionist historians (starting with Lennon) make about her early renown, her marriage lifted her from the ephemeral world of underground loft concerts and Happenings to global visibility and, more crucially, gave her access to the recording studio. The price was stiff: she became the woman everyone loved to hate; one still hears the absurd charge that she broke up the Beatles. And the verdict on her recordings was that she couldn't sing.

title: Transplant Recipient Preaches Hope
description: JOYCE WILLIG recently celebrated the 10th anniversary of what she calls her rebirth. In February 1982 she became the first adult in Connecticut to undergo a successful liver transplant.

title: Beth Tersteeg To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Glenn E. Tersteeg of Honeoye Falls, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Beth Ann Tersteeg to Jonathan Orlans Mayer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney A. Mayer of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Karen Becker to Marry Andrew Yarosh in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Gary Becker of Madison, Wis., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Karen Elaine Becker, and Andrew Yarosh, the son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Stanley Jarosz of Kinnelon, N.J.

title: Senator Kennedy and Lawyer In Washington Plan to Marry
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy and Victoria Reggie, a Washington lawyer, plan to marry later this year, the Senator's office announced today.

title: Will Aerospace Be the Next Casualty?
description: At least once a day, the giant doors open at one of the Boeing Company's plants here and another plane rolls off the line, helping the company maintain its position as the undisputed worldwide leader in commercial aircraft.

title: Catnapping to Save the Felines of the Hamptons
description: HELENA CURTIS of Sag Harbor believes in romance. It's the reproducing she has problems with. "I advocate neutering and spaying everything," Mrs. Curtis said.

title: Proposal to Expand Girls' Home Fought
description: RESIDENTS of North Valley Stream are trying to block the proposed expansion of the Wayside Home, an institution for troubled adolescent girls that borders directly on the residents' backyards.

title: Oceanographers Say Winds May Have Parted the Waters
description: Applying an expert knowledge of wind over water, two oceanographers have developed what they say is a plausible scientific explanation for the parting of the waters that enabled the Israelites to make their miraculous escape from Egypt in the biblical story of the Exodus.

title: Judging the Best in Children's Literature
description: ONCE there was a little girl who wrote down all the things she didn't like about grown-ups. "Remember this!" she said in notes to her future self. And when she became a grown-up, she did remember and was a great friend to children.

title: Troubled Housing Developers Shed Golf Courses
description: Slower home sales have driven residential developers to sell the amenities they once counted on to hasten land sales and raise prices -- their golf courses.

title: Volunteers Sift Through Archives
description: YENI NEGIN came across the handiwork of George D. Hine quite by accident. She was going through old County Court records recently when a small piece of paper fell out. Upon closer inspection, the beautifully handwritten bank note turned out to be a $3 note drawn on the Chemical Bank of New York. The warrant that had accompanied the bill, dated May 24, 1831, accused Mr. Hine of counterfeiting the money.

title: 'Life Goes On' Lives Up to Its Name
description: Will Becca Thacher, the bright, mature 16-year-old on "Life Goes On," marry Jesse McKenna, her 17-year-old high-school sweetheart? Youth aside, Jesse would be every parent's dream -- handsome, intelligent, polite -- if he were not every parent's nightmare. As viewers of the series and all the residents of its fictional town know, Jesse has tested positive for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 15, 1992
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 7 THE FIRM, by John Grisham. (Island/Dell, $5.99.) A young lawyer learns that his firm is engaged in secret, possibly illegal activities. 2 4 LOVES MUSIC, LOVES TO DANCE, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Pocket, $5.99.) Two women get caught in the snare of a serial killer. 3 4 HEARTBEAT, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $6.50.) A chance meeting of a man and a woman, both successful in television, brings them happiness. 4 * 7 FRIED GREEN TOMATOES AT THE WHISTLE STOP CAFE, by Fannie Flagg. (McGraw-Hill, $6.95.) Life in rural Alabama. 5 45 THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Bantam, $5.99.) Complex family relationships in South Carolina's low country and New York City. 6 8 TWILIGHT'S CHILD, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $5.99.) When she becomes the owner of a hotel, a woman finds herself haunted by past heartaches. 7 2 EYES OF PREY, by John Sandford. (Berkley, $5.99.) A serial killer in the Twin Cities. 8 4 TEXAS! SAGE, by Sandra Brown. (Fanfare/ Bantam, $4.99.) A woman and a man find true love while fighting to save her family's business. 9 3 THE OLD CONTEMPTIBLES, by Martha Grimes. (Ballantine, $5.99.) The passage of the male from boyhood into manhood, as practiced in various cultures. 3 43 YOU JUST DON'T UNDERSTAND, by Deborah Tannen. (Ballantine, $10.) An enigmatic 1974 murder case involving two American couples on a Pacific atoll. 7 35 A YEAR IN PROVENCE, by Peter Mayle. (Vintage, $10.) How to reduce fat in one's diet. 3 60 THE SEVEN HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE, by Stephen R. Covey. (Fireside/S&S, $9.95.) The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. LP indicates that a book is available in large prin

title: Ms. Winters To Wed in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick P. Winters of Bridgewater, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Carol Winters, to Eric David Price, a son of Donald C. Price of Aurora, Ohio, and Dr. Roslyn M. Price of Shaker Heights, Ohio. A July wedding is planned.

title:
FILM;
Hold the Caviar. Hard Times Crimp Oscar's Style.
description: Usually, the Academy Awards ceremony is Hollywood's chance to pat itself on its collective back, to thank everyone from producer to therapist, and to throw a very big party. But not this year. Like an unwelcome and uninvited guest, the economic recession has crashed the 64th annual Academy Awards. Frugality, not frivolity, marks this year's approach.

title: Is Japan Out to Get Us?
description: To the Editor:

title: Deborah Hantman, Teacher, Is Wed
description: Deborah L. Hantman, a daughter of Alan and Rosalyn Hantman of Teaneck, N.J., was married in New York last evening to Steven J. Landzberg, the son of Joan and Abraham H. Landzberg of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Louis Sigel performed the ceremony at the Columbia University Faculty House.

title: Trade and the Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: Wendy Pepper To Wed in Fall
description: Anne E. McLucas of Washington and Charles W. Pepper of Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Eustis Pepper to John Gardner Stewart, a son of Martha Stewart and David C. Stewart, both of Washington. An October wedding is planned.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Avon, Conn. 185,000 70 Rosewood Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, family room with fireplace, 2-car attached garage, 0.75 acre; taxes $2,732. Stamford, Conn. 390,000 575 Haviland Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old colonial; pool, new kitchen, h/w floors, 1 acre; taxes $4,725. Weston, Conn. 512,500 91 Eleven O'Clock Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 51-year-old French country home; stone facade, pond, 3 acres; taxes $5,762. Armonk, N.Y. 600,000 4 Devoe Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 27-year-old colonial; sun room, eat-in kitchen, family room, playroom, 1 acre; taxes $7,356. Scarsdale, N.Y. 405,000 40 Chase Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 72-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, terrace, eat-in kitchen, family room, wet bar; taxes $9,003. South Salem, N.Y. 230,000 North Lake Circle 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 17-year-old contemporary; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, family room, deck, lake rights; taxes $5,238. OTHER AREAS Commack, L.I. 169,000 12 Cobb Lane 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 32-year-old split level; den, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,800. Waldwick, N.J. 168,000 57 Stuart Street 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 46-year-old colonial; fireplace, new kitchen and stove, screened porch; taxes $4,026. Wanaque, N.J. 180,000 28 Wilson Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old colonial; new kitchen, large rooms, deck; taxes $5,071.

title: Mattingly Vows to Do Things His Way
description: Through all the annual makeovers, through all the managerial changes and front-office hysteria, there is one constant and unchanging component with the Yankees: Don Mattingly.

title: Literary Mobsters Find Enthusiastic Readers
description: That ominous fellow in the black trench coat carrying a violin case outside Federal court in Brooklyn during John Gotti's murder trial Wednesday was, purportedly, "a face."

title:
THE VIEW FROM: LITCHFIELD;
Historic Library Offers Magic, Music, Mystery And Even Some Books
description: THE Oliver Wolcott Library in Litchfield has been attracting large audiences recently for nonliterary events, like free lectures on jazz, home decorating, World War II and soap operas. Free performances for children, featuring a puppeteer, a magician and a storyteller, drew standing-room-only crowds. Tickets for a fund-raising event on March 28, a mystery skit called "Murder in the Library," sold out last month.

title: This Week
description: Prune, Plant and Read Up

title: Wall Street; Warrants, Wickes and WCI
description: If God is in the details, there is an unholy mess brewing at Wickes Companies, the California conglomerate whose empire includes the Builders Emporium chain of home improvement stores and the Kayser-Roth line of socks and stockings.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a zoning conflict in Ridgefield, Conn., referred incorrectly to the status of the case and characterized a proposed golf-course community erroneously. The developer, Ridgefield Realty Developers Limited Partnership, has reached a settlement with the town that would allow development of the community and end all pending litigation. The settlement assumes the adoption of new zoning regulations, for which final approval is pending. The community is to be built under Connecticut's Common Interest Ownership Act and is to include attached units, townhomes and single-family detached housing, and will be not be a condominium development.

title: 6 Ships, 2 Queens, Many Headaches
description: Being stubborn was not enough. Christopher Columbus also had to turn on the charm to persuade Queen Isabella to finance his trip west in 1492. "Actually, Your Majesty, I thought you were much older," he told her in Seville, brazenly stroking royal vanity. The Queen melted. "You seem to have a way with women, Columbus," she whispered suggestively. She then promptly handed over the 15th-century version of a fat check.

title: FLOWER SHOWS
description: Here is a sampling of spring flower shows in New York City. Dates and times are subject to change. Today

title:
PERFORMANCE ART;
The Art of Crash, Hum and Hiss
description: Donna Haraway wrote "we are all cyborgs" in her 1985 essay, "A Cyborg Manifesto." To Ms. Haraway, the cyborg -- a sci-fi hybrid of mechanism and organism -- is a metaphor for the increasingly entwined nature of technology and human existence. According to Ms. Haraway, a feminist historian of science, technologies can either repress or liberate, depending on who controls them. Her "Cyborg Manifesto" seems to call for a tinkerer's war, waged from below.

title: GARDENS
description: Here is a sampling of gardens in New York City. Dates and times are subject to change.

title: AIDS Children Take Toll on Families
description: ON the surface the boy's life appears like that of any other 11-year-old. He comes from a typical middle-class family and lives in a house with a pool on the North Shore, where he and family members while away the hours watching television and rented videotapes. On weekdays there are school, homework and friends. On weekends there are outings or the movies.

title: Skate Escape, Updated
description: VYACHESLAV KOZLOV will continue to play for the Detroit Red Wings while a Federal judge considers a lawsuit that contends that Kozlov is still contractually bound to his team in the former Soviet Union.

title: Atop Southern California
description: THE San Gorgonio Wilderness, a stunning mountain preserve in the San Bernardino Mountains, is just a few hours by car from the seven million people of greater Los Angeles. Yet it is remarkably untouched. On a four-day trip through its higher reaches in September, my two companions and I saw nobody a mile past the trailhead.

title: Sanitation Workers Approve a Contract
description: New York City's sanitation workers overwhelmingly approved their new contract with the Dinkins administration by a vote of 4,281 to 429. the union has announced.

title: Who Created Deficit In North Hempstead?
description: In "Assessing Blame for Nassau Deficit" [ Feb. 2 ] , North Hempstead Town Supervisor Benjamin L. Zwirn is quoted as saying:

title: Keep the Fancy Service And Give Me Low Fares
description: Your reporter misses the point in her coverage of Braniff's service from Islip MacArthur to points south. I don't fly Braniff because I want china service and filet mignon. I fly Braniff because I want the cheapest fares possible, with a schedule that works for me on an airline that is safe.

title: Glorious in Its Very Stones
description: BARCELONA

title: Spandex and Spoofs Galore: Spinal Tap Is Back
description: All over the world, from the biggest arena concert to the smallest garage, from the richest rock star to the scrappiest youth trying to win a local battle of the bands, the 1984 film "This Is Spinal Tap" is inseparable from the cult of rock-and-roll. A chronicle of the rise, fall, breakup and resurrection of the fictitious British heavy-metal band Spinal Tap, this spoof "rockumentary" is the first and final satiric word on the music industry.

title: POP
description: Today

title: A Chastened U2 Comes Down to Earth
description: Clad entirely in black leather, Bono came down from the stage on the second night of U2's two-month "Zoo TV Tour" to a long runway, where he twirled suggestively around a belly dancer as he sang "Mysterious Ways." Moments later, as his bandmates pounded out "Until the End of the World," the singer approached a video camera filming the performance, kissed its lens and then yanked it down to his crotch. An audience of 15,000 in the Miami Arena watched on a dozen video screens and roared its approval.

title: Three Suitcases: Gianni Versace
description: Come Friday, Gianni Versace leaves Milan and heads for his villa on Lake Como, "where everything we do is very casual and very luxurious." He also believes in packing light, "which is why I love jeans. They're the only pants to take. Why not? They go everywhere. Silk shirts are wonderful, too, because they can also go from poolside straight to dinner. If I must have a sport coat, I'll pack a black one, but I prefer always to have a leather jacket with me, because it is that perfect balance between relaxed and elegant. And it is such a wonderful frame for bright colors. Weekend clothes should not be neutral. They should be fun. Very happy. When I open my suitcase, it should explode with color."

title: Better Odds; Faulty Math Heightens Fears of Breast Cancer
description: The risks of getting breast cancer have been so greatly exaggerated that many women are needlessly taking potentially harmful drugs or even having their healthy breasts removed.

title: Proposal Urges Shift of Illegal-Alien Inmates
description: Two New York lawmakers have introduced a proposal in Congress to relieve state prison overcrowding by converting three closed military bases into lockups for 4,500 illegal aliens convicted of the most serious crimes.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: YOU'VE heard about the friendly side of bird watching, the sharing side. I've written about it. Others have written about it. Very compelling. Very genuine.

title: French and Indian Word Wars
description: Sacrebleu! The wife of the President of France and a phalanx of prominent citoyens want to rewrite "La Marseillaise." According to Danielle Mitterrand and her fellow revisionists, their stirring national anthem is too bellicose for their peaceful land. But their wish to soften it is politically correct humbug.

title: Problems Seen In Highlands Plan
description: Re: "Pristine Open Space: A Clash of Interests" (Feb. 9), the well-written article on the Highlands:

title: Stella Flame, Designer, Wed
description: Stella Flame, a women's clothing designer and retailer, and Michael I. Somers, an investment banker, both in New York, were married last evening in New York. Rabbi Yakov Hilsenrath officiated at the Essex House.

title: Review/Music; Uchida Is Soloist With Philharmonic
description: For some, the concert hall is a theatrical event to be seen as much as listened to. For others, the presence of musicians is tolerated for the spontaneity of gesture and immediacy of sound they add; otherwise, performers are held as obstructions, extraneous impressions to be cleared from the path extending from ear to music.

title: POSTING: Crossland Bank Designated; Neo-Classical Landmark
description: Although much younger than its ancient prototypes, the noble neo-classical temple tucked incongruously in the dark canyons of the garment district has gone through many metamorphoses. Completed in 1924 as the Greenwich Savings Bank headquarters, it became a Metropolitan Savings Bank branch in 1981, a Crossland Savings Bank branch in 1985 and a Crossland Federal Savings Bank branch in January.

title: Answering His Accuser
description: To the Editor:

title: A Symphony In the News Is the News
description: A little time has passed since John Corigliano's First Symphony appeared at the New York Philharmonic's concerts. Those performances, conducted in January by Leonard Slatkin, were part of an event that went beyond the merely musical. Passions were aroused, political and sociological nerve endings sharpened.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 15, 1992
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 THE PELICAN BRIEF, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $22.50.)
