description: A company that oversees the cleanup of hundreds of abandoned toxic-waste sites was accused today by Congressional investigators of billing the Government for millions of dollars for such expenses as parties, country club fees, season tickets to sporting events and use of a corporate airplane.

title: Investigators Look North
description: The police here said today that they were interviewing at least six people in New York in connection with allegations that a woman was raped here last March by three New York Mets.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats; Brown Seems to Relish a Narrowed Race
description: Snow snarled the highways into Hartford this morning, and so Edmund G. Brown Jr., stuck in traffic, kept a group of black and Hispanic legislators waiting for 45 minutes for a breakfast meeting at the Washington Diner.

title: Three More Arrested
description: State police in South Kingstown, R.I., arrested three more people yesterday, including a University of Rhode Island student, while an investigation continues into allegations of gambling on campus.

title: Mr. Tsongas Departs, Gracefully
description: The fatal flaw in Paul Tsongas's campaign was that his message never reached much beyond well-educated, upper-income voters. But there was something unusually principled about his quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination. He was consistent, honest, uncalculating. His presence will be missed in the forthcoming Connecticut and New York primaries.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Media; Tsongas's Negative Ads Prove to Be Fatal Error
description: Last week, five days before the Democratic Presidential primary in Illinois, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas put some catchy new commercials on the air there, attacking Gov. Bill Clinton.

title: White Voices, Black Voices
description: Following are excerpts from an editorial in yesterday's Business Day, a Johannesburg financial newspaper.

title: Air Products Names Next Chief Executive
description: Air Products and Chemicals Inc., the large supplier of industrial gases, specialty chemicals and environmental and energy system, announced yesterday that Harold A. Wagner, the company's president and chief operating officer, would become chairman and chief executive. He succeeds Dexter F. Baker, who turns 65 years old next month.

title: Reebok Is Criticized About Pay
description: Executive salaries at Reebok International Ltd. are under attack from the New York City Employees Retirement System.

title: Japan's Market Closed
description: The Tokyo stock market was closed today for Japan's vernal equinox holiday. It will reopen on Monday. On Thursday, stocks rebounded as the Nikkei index of 225 stocks rose 420.78 points, or 2.1 percent, to 20,185.09.

title: New Europe President For International Paper
description: The International Paper Company has promoted W. Michael Amick, an engineer with experience in manufacturing and human resources, to president of the company's European operations yesterday.

title: U.S. Postpones Requiring Labels On Nutrition in Meats and Poultry
description: Weighing in with its contribution to what has become an almost daily unveiling of deregulatory measures, the Agriculture Department announced today a one-year postponement in imposing requirements for nutrition labels for retail meat and poultry.

title: U.S. Says Bank Group Is Victim in Fraud Case
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan charged yesterday that a privately held petrochemicals company had defrauded a consortium of five international banks led by Chase Manhattan of more than $100 million.

title: House Proposal to Require Cable Units to Pay Royalty
description: Hoping to smooth the way for legislation that would regulate cable television rates, House lawmakers proposed a measure today that would require cable companies to pay a new royalty to television stations in exchange for carrying their programming.

title: Books of The Times; Six Generations of Mediterranean Wandering
description: Mr. Mani By A. B. Yehoshua Translated by Hillel Halkin. 368 pages. Doubleday. $22.50.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Seitel Inc. of Houston offered $12.5 million in convertible subordinated debentures, due 2002, through American Securities Corp., bearing an interest rate of 9 percent. They can be converted into stock at $9.375 a share. The company creates seismic surveys and sells data from its library.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11 DETAILS MURKY, FOCUS CLEARER

title: Acerbity and Escapism in 'Proof,' From Australia
description: This year's New Directors/New Films series begins exactly as it should, with the work of film makers whose utter assurance and originality prefigure a bright future. Jocelyn Moorhouse's "Proof," the opening feature, is a darkly clever Australian drama focusing on brilliant, wickedly manipulative characters whose attachment to one another is matched only by their mutual loathing.

title: Review/Theater; Tony Randall Directs 'The Master Builder'
description: Some theater companies take years to develop and refine a distinctive style, but the National Actors Theater has accomplished this feat in a single season. The latest example of its signature approach to the classics can be found in its production of "The Master Builder" at the Belasco Theater.

title: Pop/Jazz; Soul Singer Of the 1960's Defines His Craft
description: If fans know anything about the soul singer James Carr, who is performing at Tramps this weekend, they culled it from a chapter in Peter Guralnick's "Sweet Soul Music" or from an occasional reissue of Mr. Carr's work in the 1960's. For some time in the 70's, Mr. Carr, who has been called the world's greatest soul singer, vanished.

title: Restaurants
description: American export products may be taking a bashing in some areas, but at An American Place, the patriotic food enterprise off Park Avenue, domestic quality is at an enviable level. The restaurant reflects one man's philosophy, namely, that first-class cooking can be accomplished with exclusively native provender. Larry Forgione, the respected chef and owner of An American Place, makes a persuasive case.

title: Job Cuts Set In Bank Deal
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it expects to eliminate 10,000 to 12,000 jobs over the next three years after its planned merger with the Security Pacific Corporation.

title: Midlantic Confirms Report on Review
description: The Midlantic Corporation in Edison, N.J., has begun a review of its corporate and retail banking accounts. A spokeswoman confirmed a report of the search, which appeared in this week's issue of The Delaney Report newsletter, but said billings were less than a reported $10 million.

title: Laura Ashley Distribution
description: Laura Ashley Holdings P.L.C., the London-based clothing and home furnishings company, has hired a unit of the Federal Express Corporation to streamline its complex distribution network.

title: Chiefs Sign Krieg
description: DAVE KRIEG, the starting quarterback for the Seattle Seahawks for most of the past eight seasons, signed yesterday with the Kansas City Chiefs as a Plan B free agent.

title: Review/Photography; Trying to Bridge the Gap Between Art and Politics
description: Paul Strand (1890-1976) was without question one of the most important photographers of the 20th century, and one of the most contradictory. In his lifelong struggle to reconcile the competing demands of esthetic innovation and social documentation, Strand provides a particularly telling example in the continuing debates over the proper relationship between art and politics.

title: Some 'Worker Leasing' Programs Defraud Insurers and Employers
description: An innovative management technique that is supposed to save small businesses money and provide low-cost health benefits to workers is backfiring, costing employers, workers and insurers nationwide tens of millions of dollars.

title: Now You See It, Now You Don't
description: Rightly or wrongly, the National Football League has decided to stop using televised instant replays to determine the correctness of a field official's call. The TV audience will still get replays. But no longer will a supreme judge in a booth on high use them to second-guess the referees below.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Feb. 12 about relationships and sexuality misstated the academic affiliation of Dr. Richard J. Cross. He is emeritus professor of environmental and community medicine at the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. A letter from the university, addressed to the writer during his vacation, reached the editors belatedly.

title: Rochelle Klein Plans To Join Hal Riney
description: After months of being wooed by several agencies, Rochelle Klein said yesterday that she would join Hal Riney & Partners in New York in the new position of senior vice president and executive creative director. Her appointment takes effect on April 6.

title: Ex-Rep. Michael A. Feighan, 87; Architect of '65 Immigration Law
description: Michael A. Feighan, a 14-term Democratic Congressman from Ohio who was chief architect of the 1965 immigration act that abolished the system of quotas by national origin, died yesterday at a hospital in Washington. He was 87 years old and had homes in Washington and Cleveland.

title: Anti-Gay Crimes Are Reported on Rise in 5 Cities
description: Incidents of violence against homosexuals rose 31 percent last year, according to a survey made public today by a homosexual rights group. The group blamed political, religious and entertainment industry leaders for fostering a homophobic climate.

title: Court Ends Ban on Outside Income For Thousands of U.S. Employees
description: A Federal district judge today struck down a law that had prevented thousands of low- and mid-level Federal workers from earning outside income for writings and speeches unrelated to their work.

title:
N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: EAST;
With Seconds to Spare, Seton Hall Gets an Edge
description: Rarely does a team have a chance in its next game to reverse the terms of a galling defeat in the previous one. But after trailing for most of the way today, including by 8 points with under four minutes to play, Seton Hall had that opportunity against La Salle in opening-round action in the East Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: The Art Market
description: To the Victor a Millet

title: Blaze Breaks Out At Westbury Concert
description: A smoky fire forced the evacuation of hundreds of rap music fans from the Westbury Music Fair last night, fire officials said.

title: Let the Mud Fly
description: The Presidential primaries, when they're working right, are supposed to produce the candidate with the best chance of winning in the fall. In 1992, I think they've worked. Paul Tsongas didn't just run out of money yesterday; he didn't have the stomach for the fight. Mr. Tsongas wasn't the man to take on the President -- not because his ideas were wrong, but because you can't beat George Bush by tossing beanbags.

title: Honors
description: * Six executives will be inducted into the National Sales Hall of Fame by the the Sales and Marketing Executives of Greater New York: Joseph E. Antonini, chairman and chief executive of the K Mart Corporation; Cathleen Black, president and chief executive of the American Newspaper Publishers Association; Ewing M. Kauffman, chairman emeritus, Marion Merrell Dow Inc.; James W. Kinnear, president and chief executive of Texaco Inc.; Reginald F. Lewis, chairman and chief executive of TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc., and James E. Preston, chairman and chief executive of Avon Products Inc. The awards will be presented in New York on Tuesday.

title: 60% of Americans Favor U.S. Arts Support
description: Sixty percent of Americans say they favor using Federal tax dollars to support the arts, according to the results of a national survey released yesterday by the Louis Harris polling organization.

title: Pirates Cut Landrum
description: Two days after trading JOHN SMILEY, the Pittsburgh Pirates continued their campaign against high-salaried pitchers yesterday by cutting BILL LANDRUM, their saves leader the past three seasons.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Ehrlich and Saxophone

title: Devils Prove That McVie Is No Psychic
description: Coach Tom McVie predicted in practice this week that his team would come out flying in its first game at home after an absence of 17 days. But the Devils came out crawling tonight and suffered a 5-3 loss to the Edmonton Oilers that had them looking for a hole to crawl into afterward.

title: Talking Up Areas Outside Manhattan
description: To entice tourists to visit boroughs beyond Manhattan, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday announced details of plans for a $250,000 marketing campaign carrying the theme "New York City. Yours to discover."

title: Tsongas Keeps His Delegates
description: By suspending his campaign for President yesterday, rather than withdrawing completely, Paul E. Tsongas insures that those delegates he won on the basis of his statewide vote in primaries and caucuses will be able to go to the Democratic National Convention, even though he will not be a nominee.

title: Hearns and Barkley Both Fight for Redemption
description: The first time Thomas Hearns and Iran Barkley fought, in June 1988, their match seemed to be headed for a predictable ending.

title: Apple's New Damage Claim
description: The Microsoft Corporation said today that Apple Computer Inc. had increased the amount it is seeking in damages in its long-running copyright infringement suit.

title: Dismissal of Coach Explained by Board
description: Under court order and the threat of further legal action, the Board of Education convened a public meeting tonight to tell the most successful high school baseball coach in New Jersey why it was denying him a 34th season.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows, performances and art exhibitions in the New York metropolitan region that will be closing soon. Closing This Weekend

title: The Hour Has Come: Rams vs. Minutemen
description: The two teams were at the homes of their coaches early last Sunday evening, waiting to see where they would go in the N.C.A.A. tournament, and who would stand in the way of their dreams.

title: Review/Art; William Harnett and the Trompe l'Oeil Still Life
description: Still life wasn't a subject greatly favored by American painters of the 19th century; maybe the pull of nature outside the studio door was just too strong. But among its practitioners, William M. Harnett (1848-1892) was one of the greatest.

title: Warner-Lambert Rises on Rumors
description: Shares of the Warner-Lambert Company rose $1.50 each, to $65, amid rumors that Glaxo Holdings P.L.C. of Britain would make a bid to acquire the seventh-largest American pharmaceuticals company. "We're aware of the rumors, but we're not going to comment," said Peter Wolf, Warner-Lambert's spokesman. Glaxo officials were unavailable to comment.

title: In Victory, Thompson Salutes Opponent
description: No sooner had Georgetown registered a convincing 15-point victory over South Florida this afternoon than John Thompson, the Hoyas' coach, shook hands with members of the losing team and searched out Radenko Dobras, the Bulls' 6-foot-7-inch guard, and gave him a hug.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WENDY KOPP, the 24-year-old New Yorker who founded the Teach for America program to train and place teachers in remote rural areas, was one of 11 people honored yesterday for their contributions to their communities in 1991. They appeared at the fourth annual Kleenex Says Bless You Awards ceremony at the Willard Inter-Continental Hotel in Washington.

title: Bernard J. Lasker, 81, Chairman Of Big Board in '70 Crisis, Dies
description: Bernard J. Lasker, a former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange and fund-raiser for prominent Republicans like former President Richard M. Nixon and former Mayor John V. Lindsay of New York City, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Greenwich, Conn.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House; Bush Plans to Withhold Spending In Fight Over Economic Program
description: President Bush plans to mark the passage of his March 20 deadline for Congressional enactment of his economic-growth legislation by announcing on Friday that he will not spend $4 billion that Congress has allotted for Federal programs, White House officials said today.

title: As It Quits Implant Business, Maker Says Product Is Safe
description: Keith R. McKennon, the chief executive of the Dow Corning Corporation, ended the company's 30-year trade in silicone gel implants today by acknowledging some errors on the company's part and giving credit to the Food and Drug Administration for its fairness in trying to resolve the issue.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the fatal stabbing of a woman in the county courthouse in Milwaukee misstated the number of restraining orders sought in domestic violence cases last year in that city. The number is 6,000, not 15,000.

title: Article 499592 -- No Title
description: Theo Schoenegger had just left his job cooking at Palio. Geoffrey Lissauer, a former tennis pro, was hoping to open a restaurant in Manhattan. They met, became friends and, as the diplomats say, began a series of frank and fruitful interchanges.

title: What's Better for a Cold Bat Than a Hot Corner?
description: His forte had always been focus: Dave Magadan's ability to summon it and then maintain it. His at-bats were seminars in precision and patience, his seasonal graphs full of unbroken lines of consistent production.

title: G.O.P. Success in House Splits Party Leadership
description: Just when the House Republican leaders have forced the Democrats into retreat over the House bank scandal, they are showing more strain than glee.

title: To the Victor Go Far Too Many Spoils
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Spring Training At Bellevue
description: NOT all of baseball spring training takes place in the warmth of Florida or Arizona. That's the beauty of the thing. For Janet Gardella there's even a patch of it at Bellevue Hospital in the chill of Manhattan.

title: United Ways Challenge Method Used to Divide Their Donations
description: Wealthier affiliates of the organization that distributes millions of dollars among United Way groups throughout the New York metropolitan region are increasingly dissatisfied with a system that, they believe, takes too much out of their communities and gives it to poorer urban areas.

title: When Outsiders Get the Top Job
description: The Chrysler Corporation's decision to hand over the reins to an outsider from General Motors is a sharp departure from mainstream corporate behavior but by no means as unusual as it once was.

title: Argentine Rally Condemns Bombing
description: President Carlos Saul Menem joined a rally of tens of thousands of Argentines today to protest and "repudiate" the bombing on Tuesday of the Israeli Embassy here.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Capriati Too Tired For Pace
description: Left with more fatigue than fight following two arduous rounds against Zina Garrison and Monica Seles, Jennifer Capriati capitulated, 6-2, 6-4, to Arantxa Sanchez Vicario of Spain today in the semifinals of the Lipton Players International.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We simply did not have the resources." -- PAUL TSONGAS. [ A14:3. ]

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: METRO DIGEST DIVIDING THE UNITED WAY PIE

title: Detroit Unfazed By Japan Move
description: Detroit's Big Three were not impressed today by Japan's announcement that it would reduce the number of cars it exports to the United States to 1.65 million a year, saying the Japanese are still not playing fair. And the United States said it did not seek the cut in Japanese car exports. "It was the Japanese decision on their own," a White House official said.

title: Review/Film Festival; Acerbity and Escapism In 'Proof,' From Australia
description: This year's New Directors/New Films series begins exactly as it should, with the work of film makers whose utter assurance and originality prefigure a bright future. Jocelyn Moorhouse's "Proof," the opening feature, is a darkly clever Australian drama focusing on brilliant, wickedly manipulative characters whose attachment to one another is matched only by their mutual loathing.

title: Records Show Gotti Filed No Tax Returns for Years
description: John Gotti failed to file tax returns for six years, according to Internal Revenue Service documents the prosecution presented in his trial yesterday.

title: A Film Series With an Eye For Offbeat Relationships
description: CHRISTOPHER MUNCH'S sweetly intimate film, "The Hours and Times," takes a footnote from the history of the Beatles -- a 1963 weekend getaway to Barcelona, Spain, by John Lennon with the group's manager, Brian Epstein -- and spins it into an imaginary portrait of a relationship. One of the aims of the trip is to explore the boundaries of a friendship that is as complicated as it is close. Epstein is in love with Lennon, who doesn't return his passion but is open-minded enough to consider the possibility of sexual involvement. Finally, in an awkward encounter in a hotel bathtub, the boundaries become more set.

title: Nestle Is Set For Victory
description: After more than three months of bruising battle for control of Source Perrier S.A., it seems almost certain that Nestle, the Swiss food giant, will win, beating a rival offer from the patrician Agnelli family of Italy.

title: The Exclusive, Haute Training of Arazi
description: A videocassette is making the rounds in this small, thoroughbred-rich community an hour's drive north from Paris. It is a cassette containing footage of the Breeders' Cup Juvenile in Churchill Downs last Nov. 2, a race in which a Lamorlaye resident named Arazi exploded past 13 other horses to win by 4 3/4 lengths and become an instant Kentucky Derby favorite.

title: Review/Film; Dissension in the Ranks of a Household's 4 Wives
description: Songlian (Gong Li), the college-educated beauty who arrives at a feudal manor house at the outset of Zhang Yimou's "Raise the Red Lantern," insists on carrying her own suitcase, which is virtually the last act of independence she will be permitted during the course of the story. Forced by her stepmother into what is essentially the life of a concubine, Songlian has agreed to become the fourth wife of a feudal patriarch, a man so regal that each of his wives presides over her own separate home.

title: For Children
description: 'Stone Soup and Other Stories' William Carlos Williams Center

title: When Thrown Out, Where Do They Go?
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Prepare Veto Friendly Tax Bill
description: Struggling to settle the terms for a politically attractive middle-class tax cut in time for action before President Bush's Friday deadline, House and Senate negotiators worked tonight to try to finish sweeping tax legislation they knew would not become law.

title: Drexel Drops Adviser Plan
description: The reorganized Drexel Burnham Lambert Group has dropped plans to advise troubled companies and will instead use its $405 million junk bond portfolio to influence American corporations in which it holds interests, John Sorte, Drexel's president and chief executive, said yesterday.

title: Warmest Winter Slips (on Ice) Into History
description: Winter, or what there was of it, ended this morning at 3:48 A.M. Eastern time. The National Weather Service is counting this winter as the warmest in the 97 years records have been kept.

title: INVESTIGATORS SAY U.S. SHIELDED IRAQIS FROM BANK INQUIRY
description: Enmeshed in a doomed courtship with Saddam Hussein, the Bush Administration in 1989 and 1990 repeatedly frustrated its own criminal investigators and regulators examining Iraq's role in a multibillion-dollar bank fraud scheme in Atlanta, interviews and internal Government documents say.

title: Supreme Court Agrees to Hear Census Dispute
description: Granting an urgent request by the Federal Government, the Supreme Court agreed today to review a lower court's ruling that the Census Bureau improperly included Federal employees living abroad in calculating how to allocate Congressional seats after the 1990 census.

title: Tulane Comes From Nowhere to Oust St. John's
description: It wasn't supposed to end like this for St. John's splendid seniors, Malik Sealy, Chucky Sproling, Robert Werdann and Jason Buchanan. In their third consecutive appearance in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, it seemed unimaginable that the Redmen would be eliminated after one game by a team that had never been to the tournament.

title: Wash It or Clean It? Read the Fine Print
description: Reading garment-care labels can be a bit like getting instructions from the Mad Hatter, because they often yield more questions than answers. What to do, say, with clothing labeled: "Do not wash. Do not dry-clean." Or: "Do not clean. Spot-clean only."

title: Computrac Inc. reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Included non-recurring charges of about $ 2.3 million for restructuring and the writedown of real estate.c-Net income

title: ASA International Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Pop; Evoking A Youthful Sinatra
description: If he wanted to, Harry Connick Jr. could ride his Frank Sinatra imitation toward a lucrative career of singing old pop standards for nostalgic fans. He refuses to do so, a choice that bolstered his concert on Thursday night, the opening of a sold-out, 15-show engagement through April 7 at the Paramount.

title: Club Med Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Florida Employers Insurance Co.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
LIFE TERM UPHELD FOR ISRAEL'S AGENT
description: A divided Federal appeals court here upheld a life sentence today for Jonathan Jay Pollard, the former Navy analyst convicted of spying for Israel, rejecting his claim that the Government had breached a plea agreement that would have given him a lesser sentence.

title: Asamera Minerals reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an accounting change which resulted in a write-off of $ 6.9 million of prior years' deferred expenditures.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Circuit Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Conagra Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 23
description: b-Restated to reflect pooling of interests with Golden Valley Microwave Foods Inc., which was acquired in July 1991.Share earnings and shares outstanding reflected a 3-for-2 stock split in December 1991.

title: A Soda Seagram Didn't Swallow
description: Seagram has become the latest marketing giant to be taught a painful and expensive lesson by the soft-drink business.

title: Debit vs. Credit Cards: Pay Now, or Later
description: A year ago, Susan Frankowski, a Reading, Pa., lawyer, applied for and received a Visa debit card from the Meridian Bank of Reading, where she has a checking account.

title: Worthy Out for Season
description: Seven-time All-Star JAMES WORTHY will be sidelined for the rest of the season, the Los Angeles Lakers announced yesterday after the 6-foot-9-inch forward underwent arthroscopic surgery on his left knee.

title: A Silver-Screen Sequel?
description: John Gotti's trial was enlivened yesterday by a visit from Anthony Quinn, who was escorted by Gotti supporters and sat in the last row of spectators in the crowded courtroom.

title: Digital Equipment
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said it might start manufacturing personal computers at company factories in the United States with excess capacity. The company's personal computers are currently manufactured by the Intel Corporation, the Tandy Corporation and a Digital plant in Taiwan. The start-up of manufacturing in the United States will not affect manufacturing at these sites, said Robert Schneider, Digital's spokesman for United States desktop business.

title: Cato Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Included pretax restructuring charge of $ 10.5 million for both the quarter and year.

title: High-Stakes Poker in Albany
description: New York's primitive election and campaign financing rules are a national disgrace. Will they ever change? The answer now hinges on a high-stakes political poker game under way in Albany, and how firmly Gov. Mario Cuomo plays his reapportionment trump card.

title: Kevlin Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Included non-recurring pretax interest income of $ 73,000 on a federal income tax refund from fiscal 1987.

title: Parks Union in Contract Accord
description: The Dinkins administration has reached a tentative agreement with New York City's largest municipal union that will avert layoffs of 369 city parks workers through unpaid furloughs, city and union officials said last night.

title: A Salute to Bernstein
description: The New York City Gay Men's Chorus is to present a salute to Leonard Bernstein at 8 P.M. on Sunday at Carnegie Hall. The concert, called "Bernstein," will have Betty Comden and Adolph Green as hosts and is to benefit the chorus's AIDS Outreach Program. Among the guest artists to appear are Judy Kaye, Phyllis Newman, Kurt Ollmann and Kevin Gray. Gary Miller is to conduct. Tickets are $10 to $50. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: March 30 Is Strike Date For Players In the N.H.L.
description: Without a collective-bargaining agreement since Sept. 15 and unhappy with the current pace of negotiations, the National Hockey League Players Association announced today that its members would strike the league on March 30, the start of the final week of the regular season.

title: Judge Admonishes Gotti Over Behavior at Trial
description: John Gotti clashed with the judge in his racketeering-murder trial yesterday, exchanging sharp words in court, as the prosecution came close to completing its case.

title: Dycom Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Rangers Get Going In Detroit
description: When a former Ranger opened the scoring for the Red Wings in the first minute of play tonight, the scoreboard clock froze at "19:40." That omen didn't seem favorable for the visiting New Yorkers, who last won a Stanley Cup in 1940.

title: ACAP Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Oshawa Group (X) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: b-Included a pre-tax charge of $ 18,022,000 for restructuring and strike-related costs.c-After losses of $ 3,982,000 in the quarter and $ 9,948,000 in the year, from discontinued operations.The results are in Canadian dollars.The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: More Trouble for United Way
description: A depressing parallel to the recent ouster of United Way of America's president has emerged at the regional United Way for New York City and its suburbs. It turns out that United Way of Tri-State dismissed its president last year with a $3.3 million lump-sum pension -- astounding bounty for a charity that banks on public trust.

title: Aramed Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said comparable figures not available; company did not commence operations until Oct. 1, 1991.The company also said operating expenses for the quarter and for the year were $ 2.7 million, consisting primarily of funds expended under a contract with Gensia Pharmaceuticals Inc. to conduct research and development of second generation adenosine regulating agents.

title: F&M Financial Services Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $ 3.2 million to cover costs associated with the companies impending merger with Associated Banc-Corp. for both the quarter and year.c-Net income

title: Beauticontrol Cosmetics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Classical Music in Review
description: American Festival of Microtonal Music St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University

title: Couples With 2 Jobs Ask When Interests Conflict
description: Now that the overlapping careers of Hillary and Bill Clinton have moved to center stage, all across Washington and elsewhere dual-career couples are reviewing their lists of do's and don'ts. And those looking to prove that the nation's capital is an insular and interconnnected place need only look down the growing list of such marriages.

title: Oshman's Sporting Goods reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Included after-tax LIFO credits of $ 235,000 in the quarter and $ 12,000 in the year; the year was also after an extraordinary credit of $ 1,188,000, or 20 cents a share, reflecting adoption of FASB 96.c-Included a credit of $ 156,000 in the quarter and a charge of $ 250,000 in the year related to LIFO.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about the French race horse Arazi referred incorrectly to the track where he will make his competitive debut as a 3-year-old. The track, Saint-Cloud, is the only major one in France where horses run counterclockwise, as they do in the United States.

title: LDI Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Year-ago share results have been adjusted to give reflect the 5 percent common stock dividend distributed in July 1991.

title: Surrender? The Huskies Have Just Begun to Bark
description: Connecticut, having dispatched Nebraska with little trouble in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, pondered a bigger problem today: Ohio State. The Buckeyes, the No. 3 team in the nation, are the Huskies' assignment in a second-round game on Saturday.

title: Industrial Training Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Enzo Biochem Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1.211 million on conversion of $ 29.2 million of 9 percent convertible subordinated debentures into 5.84 million common shares.c-Net loss

To Protect More of the Montana Wilderness
description: To the Editor:

title: Wall St. Grand Prix Would Just Glorify Bedlam; Who Needs This?
description: To the Editor:

title: Religion Notes
description: Lesser Known Traditions

title: Fair Share for Whom?
description: The "fair share" mandate of the New York City Charter was supposed to allow burdened neighborhoods to say "enough" if the city decided to overload them with jails or drug treatment centers. Instead this provision, which requires officials to consider the community "burdens and benefits" of public facilities, has become the city's weapon for making sure that every neighborhood has one of each onerous facility: if a neighborhood has jails, then it needs drug treatment centers and garbage incinerators, just to make things fair.

title: Jamesway reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Included a gain of $ 2,658,000, or 19 cents a share, from an accounting change in the method of determining inflation for LIFO purposes. The periods also included LIFO credits of $ 3,988,000 in the quarter and $ 1,889,000 in the year.c-Net lossd-Included a charge for store closings of $ 10,145,000 for the quarter and $ 11,006,000 for the year; LIFO provisions of $ 3,207,000 for the quarter and $ 6,507,000 for the year, and the year also included a gain of $ 3,724,000, or 27 cents a share, from a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Savings Bank Shut
description: The Massachusetts Division of Banks closed the Bank for Savings in Malden today, bringing the number of bank failures in the state to three. The Medford Savings Bank bought the deposits of Bank for Savings' seven branches for $13.3 million. All of Bank for Savings' $392.7 million in deposits will be transferred to the Medford bank. Bank for Savings' assets totaled $396.7 million.

title: Quote of the Day
description: "We now have some reason to take Iraq's assurances of good will more seriously." ROLF EKEUS, a United Nations official [ 1:2. ]

title: Baseball Coach Loses Bid For Another School Season
description: Union High School's varsity baseball coach lost his final court bid today to be reinstated for a 34th season and a chance to extend the string of victories that has made him the most successful baseball coach in the state.

title: Care Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossThe company said the fourth quarter of 1991 reflects revenues from the operation of its Dallas and Baltimore infusion pharmacies.

title: Alliance Global Environment Fund Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Net income represented net investment income.As of Jan. 31, total net assets for the latest period was $ 95,971,816, or $ 13.89 a share, compared with $ 91,725,715, or $ 13.28 a share, for the year-earlier period.

title: Caucasus Shooting Resumes After Vance and Iran Efforts
description: Within minutes of the departure of the last Iranian peace mediators from Nagorno-Karabakh tonight, shooting started anew between Azerbaijani and Armenian militiamen along the ill-defined no-man's land between Azerbaijan and Nagorno-Karabakh, killing at least one Azerbaijani.

title: 'Bolder Approach' Is Urged for China
description: Prime Minister Li Peng called on China to "take a bolder approach to reform" today and said that its foremost task was to restructure the economy to stimulate economic growth.

title: JHM Mortgage Securities reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 926,000 from cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change.Share earnings represented units.

title: Canstar Sports Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains of $ 3.2 million, or 20 cents a share.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title:
COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
Blue Devils Make Plans To Stop Iowa's Presses
description: A cold snap followed severe storms into Greensboro overnight, but for Duke, the No. 1 seeded team in the East Regional, these remain warm surroundings.

title: American Safety Closure reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Tax Bill Veto Is No Loss
description: Congress worked feverishly and successfully to pass an economic recovery plan before yesterday's deadline set by President Bush in his State of the Union address. It need not have bothered. The bill provided paltry relief for middle-class families, no relief from the recession and virtually nothing to spur long-term growth. Worse yet, it reinstated a bevy of tax shelters of the type that were demolished by the glorious 1986 tax reform.

title: Manufacturer of Faulty Heart Valve Barred Data on Dangers, F.D.A. Says
description: Documents that reveal the dangers of a heart valve that is prone to sudden, deadly failure were kept from the public and the Food and Drug Administration, according to the agency and lawyers whose clients are suing the company.

title: Data Translation Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Calprop Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge from the writedown of properties to net realizable value of $ 7 million in the quarter and $ 8.8 million in the year. Both periods also included $ 1.2 million charge from the writeoff of the remaining asset balances for leveraged leases of computer equipment, as a result of the default of the lessee.c-Included a charge of $ 17.6 million for the writedown of properties to net realizable value for both the quarter and year.

title: Ukrainian Uses Summit to Berate Russians and the Commonwealth
description: Animosity between Ukraine and Russia broke into the open at a summit meeting of the Commonwealth of Independent States today. The Ukrainian President, Leonid M. Kravchuk, publicly lambasted Russia and the commonwealth, saying they had failed to resolve "a single political or military problem."

title: Sports of The Times; A Question Of Priorities And Patience
description: Throughout the week, Dale Brown, Louisiana State's head basketball coach, has reiterated his recommendation that Shaquille O'Neal, his 7-foot-2-inch all-America center, skip his senior year in college in favor of the National Basketball Association.

title: Forest City Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included loss on disposition of properties and other provisions, net of tax, of $ 1.3 million for the quarter and $ 1.1 million for the year.c-Net incomed-Included gain on disposition of properties and other provisions, net of tax, of $ 13.2 million, or $ 1.47 a share, in the quarter and $ 13 million, or $ 1.44 a share, in the year.

title: UMass Flies Past Rams; Orange Not Ripe for an Upset
description: Fordham University's first trip to the national collegiate basketball tournament in 21 years came to an abrupt halt tonight with an 85-58 loss to the third-seeded Massachusetts Minutemen, whose outstanding defense and flying dunks thrilled a sellout crowd of 13,514 at The Centrum.

title: U S West Will Adopt Interim Technology
description: U S West, in a departure from other large cellular-telephone operators experiencing quality and capacity problems, said yesterday that it planned to forgo converting its networks to completely digital technology in favor of a modified analog process using Motorola Inc. equipment.

title: Roy O. Allen Jr., 71; Skyscraper Architect
description: Roy O. Allen Jr., an architect whose work included the enormous 1 Liberty Plaza skyscraper in lower Manhattan and the Annenberg Building at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, died on Wednesday at Presbyterian Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 71 years old and lived in Miami.

title: Faint Hearts
description: I turned down the volume of the television and answered the phone. "Mom's had a heart attack" were my brother's words. That call began an emotionally excruciating week and a disturbing education about the politics of our health care system.

title: Bye-Bye Bambi
description: The rising deer population in the Northeast has become the bane of many suburban gardeners. Deer feed voraciously on backyard shrubs, flowers and vegetable gardens. The most severe damage often occurs in early spring, when deer are attracted to succulent new shoots. A variety of repellents are sold at garden centers and hardware stores. Read the labels carefully, as some should not be used on fruit and vegetables. Many homemade remedies also work. If you have a severe deer problem or dislike using chemicals, the most effective remedy is to place flexible netting over the most vulnerable plants during the early weeks of growth. Homemade Remedies

title: Observer; Farewell, Mrs. Keppel
description: I can't decide which line to take toward England's scandalous royals. The newsman in me clamors for shrieks of "Shame!" and "Civilization is finished!" And why not? Exclamation marks sell newspapers.

title: Iraq Agrees to Destroy Missiles To Meet U.N. Cease-Fire Terms
description: Faced with veiled American and British threats of military force, Iraq has backed down in its latest confrontation with the Security Council and agreed to destroy its ballistic missile equipment as required by the cease-fire resolution that ended the Persian Gulf war, a Council official announced today.

description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who is emerging as Europe's most powerful leader, is expected to play the role of trade envoy this weekend in private talks with President Bush at Camp David, Md.

description: There would appear to be a great movie in the story of the three Levy children or, at least, that's what Remy Gravelle (Eric Mitchell) thinks when, like the reporter in "Citizen Kane," he begins his hunt for the Levy equivalent to Kane's Rosebud.

description: b-Net incomeResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: Richard A. Ruskay Restaurateur, 44
description: Richard A. Ruskay, a restaurateur on Manhattan's Upper West Side, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 44 years old.

title: Wrong War, Wrong Weapons, Wrong Thinking
description: President Bush and Congress have declared war on recession. But they are fighting the wrong war, and, as in yesterday's tax cut jousting, both sides are using the wrong weapons.

title: Florida Acts on Prudential Broker-Teacher
description: Securities regulators in Florida have moved to discipline Prudential Securities and one of the firm's former brokers who, they say, sold investments to students in adult school classes that he taught and misled them about the risks of those investments.

title: Consumers Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 1 million charge relating to the company's decision to discontinue its individual life insurance division and a $ 550,000 charge for the termination of its Ohio banking related credit insurance activities.c-Net incomeShare earnings are after preferred dividend requirements.

title: Volunteer Ambulance Corps Fill the Gaps
description: The Tri-Community Volunteer Ambulance Corps officially came into being at 5:36 last Saturday evening when its only ambulance responded to its first emergency -- a car accident on Clarendon Road in Brooklyn. And, as the crew merrily pointed out, they beat the Emergency Medical Service to the scene by a good 20 minutes.

title: New Jersey District Is Carved Into Four
description: In a party-line vote in New Jersey that was decided by a neutral commission chairman, the Third Congressional District was carved into four pieces, throwing the Congressman from that district, Representative Frank J. Pallone, into a potential race with another Democratic incumbent.

title: Roll Call in House on Vote on a Tax Package Sponsored by the Democrats
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 211 to 189 by which the House approved a Democratic-sponsored tax bill today that would cut taxes for the middle class and raise them for the wealthy. A "yes" vote is a vote to approve the bill. Voting for the bill were 209 Democrats, 1 Republican and 1 independent. Voting against it were 40 Democrats and 149 Republicans. X denotes those not voting. There are no vacancies in the 435-member House.

title: Heir Apparent at Time Warner Is Out Amid Signs of Dissension
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that N. J. Nicholas Jr., the designated successor to the company's chairman, Steven J. Ross, had resigned and would be replaced by Gerald M. Levin, the vice chairman. Many in the company saw the unexpected resignation as a result of a clash between Mr. Ross and Mr. Nicholas, whose total 1990 compensation of $96.4 million made them the nation's highest-paid executives. But it also meant the collapse of a succession agreement central to the 1990 merger of two corporate empires, Warner Communications and Time Inc., to form the world's largest media company. Mr. Ross and Mr. Nicholas fell out over the company's ultimately successful search for foreign investors, according to two people closely involved in the company's affairs. Mr. Ross wanted to sell minority interests while maintaining control of all the company's properties, while Mr. Nicholas sought other ways for the heavily indebted company to raise money. Expressed No Regrets The company said Mr. Levin -- like Mr. Nicholas, a longtime employee of Time Inc. -- would serve as Time Warner's president and co-chief executive, the title that Mr. Nicholas had shared with Mr. Ross. Mr. Ross, the former chief executive of Warner Communications Inc., and Richard Munro, the former chairman of Time Inc., had agreed at the time of the merger that Mr. Nicholas would first share executive authority, then take charge by himself in the mid-1990's. Although the company's statement simply said Mr. Nicholas resigned, Mr. Ross, in a memo to employees, expressed no regrets and left no doubt that he favored Mr. Nicholas's departure. Several who know Mr. Nicholas well say he was intent on remaining with the company but was forced out. Mr. Ross, 64 years old, is an obsessive deal maker known for fostering loyal and skilled managers. Lately, he has been undergoing intensive chemotherapy for prostate cancer and since December has scarcely been seen at the office. Even if he returns, it is widely expected that he will focus chiefly on strategy, leaving operations to Mr. Levin. Mr. Levin and Mr. Nicholas, both 52 years old, have long been rivals. Mr. Levin was dropped from Time's board in the early 1980's as Mr. Nicholas advanced, but it was Mr. Levin who conceived of the Warner merger to further the company's global ambitions. Strong Ties Forged Since then, say some executives, Mr. Levin has forged strong ties with Warner officials, including Mr. Ross, while Mr. Nicholas did not develop the same rapport. According to one executive at Time Warner, Mr. Nicholas was asked to come back from his vacation home in Vail, Colo., for an unscheduled board meeting, but chose not to do so. The board approved the changes unanimously. Mr. Nicholas's wife, reached in Vail, said her husband would not comment. Graef S. Crystal, a leading expert on executive compensation, said Mr. Ross received compensation of $82.6 million, Mr. Nicholas $13.8 million and Mr. Levin $8.6 million in 1990. The company has disputed Mr. Crystal's figures, which include bonuses and stock options. Wall Street analysts said yesterday that they thought the news, which came after the stock market closed, was favorable for the company. "The most important ingredient for the leader of the company, and the area in which Steve excels, is broad stratetgic thinking," said Emanuel Gerard, a partner at Gerard Klauer Mattison, an investment firm. "I think Jerry is a much stronger strategic thinker than Nick and has a broader base of support from both the Time and Warner people." Industry analysts credit Mr. Nicholas, a reserved and rather formal executive, with building Time Inc.'s cable operations and watching over the company's spending. 'Difference in Philosophy' But several executives said Mr. Ross's illness, and the uncertainities it raised, had helped pushed the board to change the line of succession yesterday. But one person with close ties to the company added that such a shift was only a question of timing. "I think there has been a very, very real difference in philosophy between the two men for some time," he said. He said Mr. Nicholas had initially opposed Time Warner's decision to sell a stake in its entertainment business to the Toshiba Corporation and C. Itoh and Company, two big Japanese companies, because he opposed bringing in foreign investors. Mr. Nicholas preferred to sell some properties outright, a course that Mr. Ross opposed. Ultimately, Mr. Nicholas voted for the Toshiba deal. "You patch things up for a while, but they do not go away," said this person, who has detailed knowledge of the company's affairs. "Jerry was much more in tune with Steve's vision." Indeed, Mr. Levin had accompanied Mr. Ross to Japan to negotiate the deal. Another person with close ties to the company said Mr. Ross had approached the board about designating a new heir. In yesterday's memo, Mr. Ross acknowledged that he and Mr. Nicholas had clashed over the company's direction. "Nick's decision was based on his sense that there was sufficient difference regarding our strategic focus, between him on the one hand and the board and his management colleagues on the other,' Mr. Ross's memo said. Mr. Ross said that Mr. Nicholas had left with "a sense of great and well-deserved pride" in the company's achievements and "a host of friendships forged during the merger." As for Mr. Levin, Mr. Ross was effusive, saying he "had been unfailingly impressed by Jerry's judgment, his insightful understanding of all our businesses and his commitment to fully realizing Time Warner's enormous potential." In two years, Mr. Levin has come to be a favorite with the board, distinguishing himself in explaining complicated financial and strategic actions. Mr. Levin had a good sense ofthe board members' personalities and outlooks, one person close to the board said. Several executives in the industry say Mr. Levin was also well liked by Warner's chairman, Robert Daly, and its president, Terry Semel, and had a strong knowledge of the movie business from his days at Home Box Office Inc., a Time Warner cable television subsidiary. Mr. Nicholas, meanwhile, did not manage to form alliances with the top executives at Warner Brothers, the movie studio, and Warner Records, one executive said. Praise for Rising Executive Yesterday's news shows that Mr. Levin made a strong comeback. Until yesterday, Mr. Levin had served as chief operating officer, but had gradually been accruing power for a year. Mr. Levin was also a favorite of Mr. Ross's closest confidant, Ed Aboudi, who worked with Mr. Ross in negotiating the merger. In a recent interview, Mr. Aboudi spoke glowingly of Mr. Levin but failed to mention Mr. Nicholas. In Los Angeles, film executives predicted that the shift would have no substantive effect on Warner Brothers. Officials at the studio declined to comment. But film executives close to the studio said the parent company had adopted a hands-off policy towards decision-making, even on controversial Warner films, like Oliver Stone's "J.F.K." "It's always been a hands-off operation, and we expect that it will continue to be so," said one film executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The executive said the emergence of Mr. Levin was viewed positively in the film community. "You've got a guy who comes more from the creative side, like Steve Ross," as opposed to someone with a numbers bent, he said. ime Warner Inc. said yesterday that N. J. title: Your Taxes; Many Forgo Cut In Withholding
description: When President Bush unilaterally increased the take-home pay of millions of workers in January, not by cutting taxes but by changing the formula by which payroll taxes are withheld, he confidently declared: "Something tells me that a number of taxpayers will take me up on this one."

title: Nassau Clerk Is Faulted for Backlogs
description: The mounting backlog in the Nassau County Clerk's office, which has caused a legal nightmare, stems in part from County Clerk Harold W. McConnell's reluctance to computerize operations, despite repeated appropriations to pay for the work.

title: Hans Jelinek, 81, Dies; An Artist and Teacher
description: Hans Jelinek, a graphic artist and professor emeritus of art at City College, died on March 13 at the DeWitt Nursing Home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

title: Patents; Levitating Materials For Testing
description: The founders of a small research company in Northbrook, Ill., have invented a new way to levitate small objects, using a combination of air pressure and powerful sound waves.

title: Budget Talks Place Mayor In a Squeeze
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins found himself squeezed yesterday in his continuing attempt to balance the budget and the priorities of the city's labor unions.

title: Theft of Box-Office Receipts Is Reported at 'Catskills' Theater
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's Office said yesterday that it was investigating allegations of financial impropriety in the box office of the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, home of the comedy "Catskills on Broadway."

title: CHRONICLE
description: The latest, but probably not the last, word out of Buckingham Palace on the row between the DUKE and DUCHESS OF YORK is: "apologies." CHARLES ANSON, Queen Elizabeth II's press secretary, has apologized to the Queen and to the Duchess for off-the-record remarks that led PAUL REYNOLDS, the BBC's diplomatic correspondent, to report, "The knives are out for Fergie in the palace."

description: Canada's northernmost civilian community, on a latitude of 76 degrees north, 900 miles from the North Pole, has 134 people, a school, a medical center, a cooperative store, a church, 50 snowmobiles, 85 dogs and no locked doors.

title: Confidence Indexes Show Brighter Consumer Outlook
description: Consumer confidence, which had remained gloomy even as consumer buying had begun to rise, appears to be moving up again after a long slide.

title: Guard Is Killed In an Ambush In Brooklyn
description: A 68-year-old armored-car guard was shot to death and his partner was wounded yesterday morning by robbers who came up behind them outside a check-cashing store in an industrial section of Brooklyn, the police said. The killers escaped with $186,000.

title: S.E.C. in Action Against Brokerage
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission went into Federal court yesterday in an effort to halt what it says are abusive practices by Stratton Oakmont, a fast-growing brokerage operation in Lake Success, L.I. title: Dow Up 14.99, to 3,276.39; Broad Market Off

title: New Chairman Elected At Brooklyn Academy
description: Bruce C. Ratner, a real estate executive, has been elected chairman of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The announcement was made this week by the office of Harvey Lichtenstein, president and executive producer of the academy.

title: Police to Study Medical Data
description: Police investigators here plan to review medical records of the woman who has alleged that she was raped by three Mets last spring.

title: Yankees' Shake-Up Affects Michael's Role
description: Saying that their organization has been in disarray and losing money since owner George Steinbrenner was banished from baseball in July 1990, the Yankees today restructured their front office and named limited partner Barry Halper vice president of baseball operations.

title: Louis Gerstman, 61, a Specialist In Speech Disorders and Processes
description: Dr. Louis J. Gerstman, a neuropsychologist who was a co-inventor of the talking computer portrayed as HAL in the movie "2001: A Space Odyssey," died on Tuesday at his home in Malvern, Pa.

title: U.S. Is Working on Soviet Aid Package
description: The State Department is working on a large-scale aid package for the former Soviet Union, but the White House remains hesitant to move forward on the multibillion dollar package, Congressional and Administration officials said today.

Henley Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $ 60,000,000, or $ 3.05 a share, for the quarter and a loss of $ 109,000,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations and the quarter reflects a gain on the sale of the company's 7 million shares of Fisher Scientific International Inc. stock. The full year reflects adjustment of the carrying value of goodwill related to a change in the company's operational focus, and the adoption of Financial Accounting Standards No. 106, related to post-retirement benefits, and a $ 20 million restructuring charge related to Fisher Scientific.c-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 3,000,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $ 53,000,000, or $ 2.69 a share, for the year and the year also included a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 122,000,000.d-Included income of $ 2,000,000, or 10 cents a share, and a loss of $ 25,000,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations, and the quarter and year included an extraordinary credit of $ 47,000,000, or $ 2.39 cents a share.Latest quarter and year's losses from continuing operations of $ 33,000,000 and $ 483,000,000, respectively, reflect $ 31 million and $ 423 million, respectively, of nonrecurring and restructuring charges.The company said the extraordinary item reflects the effect of the company's purchase of Pneumo Abex public debt securities.The accounting adjustment reflects the implementation of FAS 106 on an immediate recognition basis effective Jan. 1, 1991.

title: For Bereft Father, a Dark Cloud Clears
description: Every single day for the last two years, Jose Dominguez says, the killing of his son has hung on his mind like a dark cloud. And every day for more than a year, he has lived with the consequences of a single moment, when he pulled out a gun and shot his son's killer in the back on the steps of the Bronx County Courthouse.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: 'Tales of Malamud' New York University Theater 35 West Fourth Street Through tonight

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats; Clinton Says Golfing at All-White Club Was Mistake
description: After months of presenting himself as a Southern candidate with a good civil rights record, Gov. Bill Clinton has suddenly found himself under criticism for a classic gesture of racial separation: playing golf at an all-white country club.

title: Let Germany Do It
description: After Richard Nixon scolded President Bush for not giving more aid to Boris Yeltsin, Mr. Bush pleaded other demands on U.S. resources. Now the Administration is putting together a comprehensive aid package for Russia and other states of the former Soviet Union. Mr. Bush, however, should defer to German leadership in an international aid program.

title: Death Toll in Israeli Embassy Bombing Rises to 32
description: The Death toll from the bombing of the Israeli Embassy here Tuesday rose to 32 today as investigators tried to sort out reports that a member of a German terrorist organization, the Red Army Faction, had entered Argentina only days before the bombing.

title: Patents; A New Spinnaker for Racing Yachts
description: Lincoln F. Baird, an avid amateur sailor in Los Angeles, won a patent this week for a new spinnaker -- the large, triangular headsail on racing yachts -- that he says fills up with wind better and can propel a boat much faster than traditional sails.

title: Decision Goes to Barkley After a 12-Round Brawl
description: The way Iran Barkley fought Thomas Hearns tonight, he could have staged the bout in a subway token booth.

title: Hills Department Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 12,480,000, or 63 cents a share, for both the quarter and year, and pretax charges from store closing and reorganization of $ 1,065,000 in the quarter and $ 5,072,000 in the year.c-Net loss and included pretax charges from store closing and restructuring of $ 242,022,000.

title: Washington Governor Signs Measure on Obscene Music
description: Challenging the recording industry, Gov. Booth Gardner of Washington today signed a measure that would outlaw selling to minors music deemed obscene.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The House; COUNSEL TO REVIEW HOUSE OVERDRAFTS
description: Intervening in the House bank scandal, Attorney General William P. Barr today appointed a retired Federal appeals court judge as a special counsel to review the check-writing practices of lawmakers and the operations of the bank.

title: Alice Marriott, 82, Scholar Who Wrote Of American Indians
description: Alice Lee Marriott, an anthropolgist and author who helped popularize American Indian culture and the role of Indian women, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Oklahoma City, Okla. She was 82 years old and lived in Oklahoma City.

title: Fedders Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Computer Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a special charge of $ 105,000 for severance and other personnel related expenses.c-Net income

title: CHRONICLE
description: Some 200 prominent scientists from around the world are gathering this weekend at Columbia University to pay homage to "the Stork," their revered teacher and mentor, and the man who brought them into the world of science.

title: Patents; Coffee Percolator That's Disposable
description: Kraft General Foods has patented an inexpensive, disposable coffee percolator that allows a person to brew a single cup of coffee in a microwave oven and then throw the percolator away. A lawyer for the company said, however, that it had no immediate plans to market the invention.

title: Corrections
description: A short article by The Associated Press in Business Day yesterday about a bid won by United Airlines against American Airlines to lease 16 takeoff and landing slots held by Trans World Airlines at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago misstated American's offer for the slots. It was $65,000 a month for each slot.

title: Munsingwear Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Jan 4
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 51,239,000 from a gain on forgiveness of debt, and included income of $ 1,927,000 from disposal of discontinued operations.c-Net loss and included a loss of $ 25,080,000 from discontinued operations, which included a loss of $ 25,384,000 on disposal of discontinued operations.The latest year's income from continuing operations included a gain of $ 1,987,000 on closing of facilities, a $ 8,211,000 reorganization charge and a $ 8,021,000 gain for fresh start reporting adjustments.The year-earlier period's loss from continuing operations included a charge of $ 2,477,000 related to closing of facilities and a $ 648,000 reorganization charge.The company said that all share earnings were not meaningful because of its Chapter 11 reorganization. The company emerged from reorganization in November 1991.

title: Macy Can Extend Lease Decision
description: The Federal bankruptcy judge presiding over the bankruptcy proceedings of R. H. Macy & Company gave the company more time to determine which of its 422 leases it will retain or reject.

title: Domco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.Latest figures included the results of Azrock from the Jan. 31, 1991 acquisition.Year-ago results are restated.

title: DePaul Tripped by Giant Killers
description: New Mexico State taught DePaul this afternoon that bigger is not always better.

title: New Jersey Panel Redraws 14 Congressional Districts Into 13
description: In a strict party-line vote decided by its neutral chairman, a bipartisan commission carved Representative Frank J. Pallone Jr.'s Third Congressional District into four pieces today and threw Mr. Pallone into a potential race with another Democratic incumbent, Bernard J. Dwyer.

title: Surgery for Quintana
description: The cure may not have been worse than the disease, but for Red Sox first baseman CARLOS QUINTANA, who broke his arm in a car accident in Venezuela last month and will miss at least half the season, it was bad enough to require a second operation.

title: MILITARY IS SEEN STALLING ON OZONE
description: A new policy aimed at eliminating the use of ozone-depleting chemicals by the military is being blocked at the top levels of the Pentagon, military officers said today.

title: Shabby Lives in Brooklyn, With Camera Looking On
description: Nick Gomez makes an impressive debut as the writer and director of his first feature, "Laws of Gravity," a vividly acted and extremely well photographed tale of three days and nights on the Brooklyn streets. The film will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art today at 9:30 P.M. and tomorrow at 3 P.M. in the New Directors/New Films Series.

title: Cineplex Odeon reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 13,328,000, which included a $ 4,028,000 loss from discontinued operations and a $ 9,300,000 loss from the sale of the operations.c-After income from discontinued operations of $ 7,733,000, or 16 cents a share, which included a $ 11,380,000 loss from discontinued operations and a $ 19,113,000 gain from the sale of the operations.The latest year also included other expenses of $ 5,290,000, compared with $ 65,607,000 in 1990.

title: A Turn to Peace in Afghanistan
description: Even as old regional wars wind down elsewhere, blood still flows in Afghanistan. When Moscow withdrew its forces three years ago, everyone assumed that Afghan insurgents would make short work of Soviet puppets in Kabul. But the divided guerrillas were unable to vanquish an unexpectedly resilient President Najibullah, the ruthless cop whom the Soviet Union had installed in power in 1986.

title: Celutel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Colts Sign Matich
description: Offensive lineman TREVOR MATICH, left unprotected by the New York Jets, signed with the Indianapolis Colts yesterday as a Plan B free agent. Matich, a seven-year veteran, has played center, guard, tackle and tight end for the Jets since joining the team as a Plan B free agent on March 19, 1990. (AP)

title: Efforts to Resolve Nassau's Government Impasse Spin Into a Vortex of Confusion
description: Despite a fast-moving flurry of union votes, court decisions, and official pronouncements today, Nassau County government remained stalled in a budgetary and political gridlock as thick as any traffic tie-up on the Long Island Expressway.

title: Wall St. Grand Prix Would Just Glorify Bedlam
description: To the Editor:

title: Legislators from Two States Attack Commuter Tax Plan
description: Two Republican legislators from New Jersey today won the support of two Republican colleagues from New York State in the "border war" between New York City and its suburbs over Mayor David N. Dinkins's proposal to raise the city's commuter tax.

title: Courier Falls to Chang And Loses No. 1 Spot
description: Jim Courier threw down his racquet as if the handle were burning him, and then, using his fingertips, he picked it up by the frame and dangled it, like a piece of refuse, at arm's length. He spit in the general direction he wished one of his many forehand miscues had taken -- across the net rather than into the stands.

title: Colortech Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Kenya Orders Ban on Political Meetings
description: President Daniel arap Moi banned all political meetings today, citing weeks of ethnic violence that Government opponents say has been allowed to spread in order to undermine a movement for greater democracy.

title: Powell Criticizes Further Military Cuts
description: Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, today issued the sharpest criticism to date of a plan in the House of Representatives to double the size of military budget cuts the Bush Administration had proposed for next year.

title: White House Allows Some Advice At Public Clinics About Abortion
description: Picking its way through the minefield of abortion politics, the Bush Administration said today that doctors in federally financed family planning clinics may give limited advice on abortions, though nurses and counselors may not.

title: Huge Fund Turns Up Proxy Heat
description: California's influential public pension fund turned up the heat on 10 companies today -- including giants like I.B.M., Time Warner and Polaroid -- by threatening to vote against the re-election of their directors if they do not change policies that it contends give short shrift to shareholders.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY GOTTI V. GLASSER

title: Patents; Nuclear Generator for Exploring Mars
description: The Fairchild Space and Defense Corporation, a unit of the French company Matra S.A., this week patented a nuclear-fueled turbocompressor to generate heat and electricity on the planet Mars.

title: Indictment In Marketing Tax Shelters
description: A New Jersey man has been accused of engineering a large tax shelter scheme that was marketed to wealthy, well-known investors.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Informal Latin Economy Saves Day
description: On every downtown city block here, men and women sit hawking their wares. From Bic lighters to Snickers candy bars to Brut shaving cream to Japanese television sets.

title: Human Rights Picture in Tunisia Is Grim
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; Women Who Fight On When There Is No Hope
description: In "Vinegar Tom," Caryl Churchill set out to write a play about witches that did not have any witches in it, a play, she said, "not about evil, hysteria and possession by the devil, but about poverty, humiliation and prejudice." The result, though not as richly textured as Miss Churchill's most mature work, is fueled by the fierceness of its conviction. As staged by Marjorie Ballentine at Theater Labrador/New Georges, it is provocative theater as well as a conscience-baring feminist document.

title: A Deal Is Reached On Sale of Patriots
description: JAMES BUSCH ORTHWEIN, the brewery family magnate who wants to re-establish a National Football League team in St. Louis, might or might not get his wish, but by the time the National Football League picks two new expansion franchises in October, Orthwein, at least, will have had some practice as an N.F.L. owner, and the N.F.L., moreover, will owe him a very big favor.

title: Pic 'n' Save reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-Included one-time charge of $ 19.3 million related to a proxy fight and associated restructuring expenses.

title: 2 Innings, 5 Runs: Gooden Is Dented But Undaunted
description: Dwight Gooden was wild. Dwight Gooden was hit. Dwight Gooden was able to throw fastballs no harder than 87 miles per hour with regularity. Dwight Gooden was taken deep by Craig Biggio. Dwight Gooden was yanked after only two and one-third innings against the Astros in his first official start of the spring.

title: In Korea, Time Runs Short for Inspections
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Some 2,000 players went into action this afternoon at the start of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals. The immediate focus of attention is the four-session Open Pair Championship, but most of the stars are looking forward to Sunday, when six days of Vanderbilt Knockout Team play will begin.

title: Colombian to Be Questioned on Editor's Killing
description: The police and Federal agents investigating the slaying of a crusading Hispanic journalist arrested a 21-year-old Colombian yesterday as a suspect in a 1989 murder. The man has ties to one of the leading South American drug cartels, law-enforcement officials said.

description: In New York, they'd like you to think of it as a sort of National Football League in the spring. Anyplace else, it's the World League. And it's back, with its shortened name, starting today.

title: Keough Goes Home
description: Four days after being hit in the head by a foul ball and having brain surgery, MATT KEOUGH was discharged from Scottsdale (Ariz.) Memorial Hospital yesterday and returned to his home in California. He is not expected to be able to begin pitching for three months.

title: Agreement Will Open Skies To Reconnaissance Flights
description: A long-sought agreement to open the skies over the former Soviet Union, Europe and North America to reconnaissance aircraft flights was reached in Vienna today.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primary; Clinton, Facing Hurdles, Opens New York Drive
description: Gov. Bill Clinton, gliding toward the Democratic nomination, today begins his campaign in New York, where he needs not only to defeat Edmund G. Brown Jr. decisively on April 7 but to lay the groundwork for victory next November in a pivotal state that no Democratic nominee can afford to lose.

title: Review/Dance; Liveliness Of Film, But Onstage
description: What viewers do not see is as important as what they do in "Channels/Inserts," a work from 1981 that was given a lively revival by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company on Thursday night at the City Center (131 West 55th Street).

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Economic Issues; TAX BILL IS PASSED BY THE DEMOCRATS AND BUSH VETOS IT
description: Clearly foreshadowing the general election campaign to come, President Bush and Congressional Democrats slugged it out today over taxes, spending and the affections of the middle class, their favorite election-year economic issues.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Honors, too, this weekend, for DR. HENRY J. HEIMLICH, who will be the guest of honor at a dinner tomorrow evening, to promote a new museum in Israel to be named after him. Dr. Heimlich, 72, is known for revolutionizing first aid with the Heimlich Maneuver, the simple technique that he invented for aiding choking victims.

title: A Writer Adrift in a Movie-Mad World
description: The rueful Turkish film "A Heart of Glass" could be called a comedy of mild manners if it was a shade less hangdog, and if it had been made with more flair. As it is, Fehmi Yasar's story of a hapless screenwriter in Istanbul, and of the unlikely adventures that lead him to rural Anatolia, is more notable for its occasional droll flourishes than for its ability to sustain interest.

title: Post Office Joins Recycled Paper Drive
description: The United States Postal Service, changing with the times, is also changing the paper it uses to make 29-cent stamped envelopes. On May 1 it will reissue 19 designs from the past year on recycled paper.

title: Elinor Montgomery, A Volunteer, Dies at 54
description: Elinor White Montgomery, until recently the board chairwoman of the New York City School Volunteer Program, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 54 years old.

title: The Fed Is Investigating Dealings in U.S. Note
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York confirmed yesterday that it was conducting an investigation into a possible squeeze of seven-year Treasury notes.

title: Inverness Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 29.5 million writedown in the carrying value of its oil and gas properties at Dec. 31.c-Net incomeThe company noted that it changed its fiscal year-end during 1990 to Dec. 31 from June 30, and it did not provide figures for the year ended Dec. 31, 1990.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Appeals Panel Supports Broker on Margins
description: A Federal appeals court in Chicago, in a case stemming from the 1987 stock market crash, has ruled that a broker has the right to increase a customer's required down payment on an options investment sharply, with virtually no notice.

title: Hughes Supply reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net incomeThe company said sales in the fourth quarter did not reflect any improvement in the construction markets served by Hughes. The company also said fiscal fourth-quarter results were hurt by several nonrecurring charges, including a $ 675,000 charge for petroleum-related environmental clean-up costs, restructuring charges of $ 550,000 related to the reorganization of certain subsidiary operations, and the write-off of $ 625,000 for certain inpaired or abandoned fixed assets. The charges are pretax.

title: Tatar Area in Russia Votes on Sovereignty Today
description: While the heads of government of the Commonwealth of Independent States try to sort out their considerable problems today in Kiev, the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, is struggling to cope with a considerable threat to the unity of Russia itself here in the eastern part of European Russia, populated heavily by Turkic-speaking Tatars.

title: British Air Has Stake in German Line
description: British Airways P.L.C., which has made no secret of its desire to make Berlin a major center for serving Central and Eastern Europe, said today that a new company in which it has a large interest had acquired Delta Air, a German regional airline.

title: Chinese Smugglers' Lucrative Cargo: Humans
description: In growing numbers, ships from mainland China are sailing toward America, their holds packed with a frightened and seasick human cargo destined mostly for labor in the restaurants and sweatshops of New York's Chinatown.

description: b-Net loss
